review_title: Good to pay almost all of your bills
pros: Teammates were awesome. That's it really.
cons: Schedule was awful and unchanging for the 2 years I was there. You live paycheck to ALMOST your next paycheck with no hope of having a livable wage in sight. I was more than qualified for and applied to dozens of jobs that I could have absolutely blown out of the water for SNHU but every internal application was completely ignored with zero reasons provided. It is weird being told that they embrace leadership and experiences only to have them completely overlooked while being made to feel unimportant, like my extensive list of life and professional experience meant nothing next to the kid still in college who has gone nowhere and done nothing with their life yet. And we both made barely 19 an hr. It took many months since leaving to get my self esteem and self worth back after being overlooked that many times while trying as hard as I could to be as valuable as possible. Truly a shame. DO NOT start in admissions as a means to get your foot in the door. It's a door to nowhere.

pros: Benefits, flexible hours if you don't work directly with students

Those who speak up trying to make progressive changes or acknowledge department gaps are silenced and then prevented from moving up or outside of their roles. We're told to challenge the status quo, but leaders clearly aren't bought into that. Pay is also a huge issue that gets ignored. They would rather give out free t-shirts once or twice a year than pay their employees more. Management gets paid just fine, but that just makes them unable to understand employee struggles with pay.

review_title: Started great but took a bad turn during COVID
pros: The best parts of this job for me were the benefits, especially the PTO, and the remote flexibility.
cons:
There is a huge divide at this university. I started working for SNHU Online and then my office was merged with a campus office towards the end of my time at SNHU. There was a huge initiative going on at the University to merge the two sides (campus and online) into one, which is great in theory but it was not executed well at all. The folks on campus are very much traditionalists and do not take well to people moving from SNHU Online to campus. It was a bit of a toxic work environment during the mergers. There were multiple online offices that merged with campus offices and because this was poorly handled on all accounts by University leaders, there were a lot of people who left the University completely because they did not feel respected or supported. One my merged team alone, 5 people left within a 6-month period and some of them were long-time employees of the University.

There is not much room for growth at this University. They are constantly posting new jobs, but the problem is that there are so many employees looking to move out of Admissions or Advising that each position gets flooded with applicants.

Some students treat staff/faculty terribly and the University does very little about it. They will tell you to fill out a dispute form or speak to someone on the Dispute Resolution team and nothing really ever comes of it.

job_title: Online Adjunct Instructor in Manchester, NH
pros: The University does a good job of providing orientation training to help instructors learn SNHU teaching policies. Excellent instructor portal that contains a wealth of information to instructors. All activities for onboarding can be done remotely and teams are responsive to questions. Most students are engaged in their coursework, but there are the usual students who are just there to get the financial aid disbursement then stop participating. Team leads are assigned to every course so there is as first line of support for instructors if needed. Each course has an instructor resource which provides an excellent overview of each module and answer keys where appropriate. Instructors have extreme flexibility in adding additional resources, but also have a good base for ensuring all students in all sections are getting the same grading.
cons: Course assignment is incredibly unreliable and frustrating. You are typically approved for 3 to 5 courses on hiring, but may not be assigned courses each term even though the max course load per year is 10. The standard response is that there are too many approved instructors for courses, so assignment is not guaranteed; however, for many courses, multiple instructors are assigned two sections repeatedly.

There are some very smart people with good intentions, but they all keep a low profile in a sea ruled by sharks. Some managers have absolutely no business managing – they are controlling freaks with mental insecurities, bullying and micro-managing their staff into submission. review_title: Not as great as people think
pros: Amazing benefits. If you live in NH, you will not find any other company that even comes close to SNHU’s benefits. They are truly unique and top notch. During COVID the company did not do layoffs and Paul (the president) said he would see property before he lets any employee go due to budget cuts. He truly cares about the mission of the university.
cons: The reviews here are  misleading as SNHU has been actively working on their score for years. HR sends out reminders after 30ish days of employment asking all employees to submit reviews. Naturally, being new to a company they will be positive and not many employees follow up once they start to see the downside. The pay is FAR below market value. Especially if you are moving within the organization. Found out my peers were making over $50k than those that moved internally through the organization. With Covid there has been a massive shift of culture. SNHU is no longer the dream company where even if you were not paid well, at least you had a great organization and wholesome culture. Sadly many departments are massively overworked, under paid, not valued, and often times bullied by leadership. Executive leadership continues to change priorities and shift in “favorite” departments. We were consistently asked to shift in our department goals so we could never truly produce quality work and only ever got to do rework. Sadly I think SNHU needs a wake up call and determine what they want ti accomplish over the next few years. I do truly believe there are amazing people here that want to make a difference in peoples lives. They just have lost sight and staff is starting to become unmotivated. I have lost track with how many talented people have left the organization within the past few years.

pros: SNHU really cares about their employees and practice what they preach
cons: Pay is a little less for the amount of work being done.

pros: Work culture seems great if you are at higher levels or in leadership positions. Great retirement benefits.
cons: I applied to a job I was absolutely qualified for but I suppose they had someone else in mind for it and told me they needed people to fill extended finance counselor positions. I was misled regarding the nature of the position and the hours. I was over-qualified, having a masters degree and placed in a call center position. It was ridiculously and unnecessarily complicated.

review_title: I keep waiting to find out the catch, none so far
pros: SNHU is the first actually collaborative workplace I've worked for. IDK if it's the mission focus, high quality culture filtering during the hiring process, or just something in the water, but I've been consistently wowed by my coworkers and management on their earnestness and positivity. I've encountered almost no infighting, resource guarding or similar. The on-boarding was fairly smooth, especially as a remote worker. After 6 months, I was asked to join a focus group so they could continue to improve on-boarding. That's one of several times I've seen management working on real continuous improvement, and not resting on "good enough", both internally towards employees and externally towards the students. Town halls allow anonymous questions and leadership doesn't seem to shy away from tough questions. Work-life balance is very good, and supported both at my direct manager level and seemingly from upper management, though I have not put this to the test yet. The benefits are the best I've ever had. Extremely high quality health insurance (not high deductible or any of that bull) at a reasonable co-pay on day 1, excellent, 9% contribution to retirement whether or not you also contribute, though this doesn't start immediately. And free tuition for you, spouse and children.
cons: The university has grown extremely quickly and it shows sometimes. Finding out who owns what product or process can be a scavenger hunt. Shadow departments and products exist.

review_title: Great pay, benefits; but impossible to advance to other internal roles.
pros: Comparatively speaking - SNHU has excellent pay, benefits, and a positive culture, even if it is a little bit summer-campy at sometimes for those of us in student experience. Some flexibility in scheduling is offered, which makes this a good fit for working parents. Ability to work fully remote.
cons: Almost impossible to advance into other departments, even with a lateral move. There are around 800 advisors, which makes it hard to stand out. I've had a hiring manager tell me this in an interview - "There are hundreds of advisors, you're pretty lucky you got an interview. Why should we hire you?" This situation is further worsened due to the fact that we're hiring fully remote in nearly 20 states, so while it was challenging to make lateral moves or advances inter-departmentally, it's now nearly impossible, due to the flooding of the candidate pool.

pros:
My top 3 Pros for SNHU are:
1) Benefits- Their insurance package is wonderful. They have full medical, dental, and vision insurance. 
2). Culture- This is a diverse workplace with a healthy culture. The people at SNHU are amazing and work hard to have a diverse perspective. I've always been able to give my opinion even if it is different from the majority. 
3) Growth Opportunities- They work hard to develop their employees and give them opportunities for growth. SNHU has an entire program for growth opportunities where you are able to take "courses" to learn new skills. I am constantly getting invites for seminars and opportunities to learn new skills.
cons: The only element that has been a real adjustment for me is that even though I am salaried my time is tracked like an hourly employee. It's not necessarily a Con but just something different and took some getting use to. This makes the work/life balance a little tricky.

review_title: Great Company to Work For - Too Much Campus vs. Online
pros:
1. SNHU is an innovative university and continuously seeking ways to break the education mold. It creates a fun environment to test new ideas or be part of the change. 
2. Great benefits - seriously, remarkable benefits.
3. SNHU is starting to offer more professional development opportunities for all employees.
4. DEI is a significant focus in leadership, and great work is being done in this area.
cons:
1. The campus is undergoing a large transformation that has not been successful. It has created a loss in valuable employees, a decrease in student numbers, and a less enjoyable campus experience for faculty, staff, and students.
2. There is too much campus versus online. SNHU tries to create "one university," but it's clear the recent transformation work on campus was actually an assimilation. Campus life lost so much value while online sacrificed nothing. Online thinks they are superior, and campus things online runs too much like a business or profit school.

review_title: Benefits Trap You in a Dead-End Position
pros: Great benefits. Good PTO, health insurance, and professional development opportunities. Everyone is nice and the culture is friendly, for the most part.
cons: Team leads are trained to gaslight employees and have no power other than to dismiss valid concerns. If team leads were properly vetted instead of leadership hiring their friends, the problems regarding change fatigue could be lessened significantly. Benefits and slight raises, while not enough, trap you within the University. Advising/SFS/Admissions gain no unique professional skills but become stuck making too much money for their skillset. Upon discovering that there is very little opportunity for upward movement; if you want to leave, you need to start over at another company for a lower salary. Advising is moving quickly toward a call-center; and now we cannot decide when we take breaks on mandatory night shifts. The shift from a unique and personal advising model will be the end of the great "customer experience" that our students are used to. If you want to treat your employees and business as a call center, you will receive call center quality interactions.

pros: The benefits are nice, the people are nice, I feel lucky to have had job security throughout the pandemic.
cons: Cultish. You feel very brainwashed by the environment for the first year and then it starts to wear off. You are encouraged to keep up the act so that new hires stay in this state for as long as possible. Leadership is very unorganized, I can tell they are doing their best but they are not provided with clear expectations or tools. We have numeric goals that we need to meet, but no commissions or bonuses come with meeting these goals. We have yearly performance evaluations that have nothing to do with job performance and everything to do with how cooperative we are acting and how good we are with keeping the new hires brainwashed. We are paid very poorly with a 4% raise each year. You do not get raises based on performance, but there are classes with homework assignments that can be done to be eligible for a raise. Most of us feel so overworked that there is no time to complete these weird cult classes to shape our personalities into their mold in order to get a $1 raise.

job_title: Online History Instructor in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
- Varied student types, so never a hum-drum experience in the classes
- Tech systems work smoothly
- Tons of helpful resources on getting tech solutions
- Lots of support systems in place for student success
- Lots of opportunities to remotely engage with direct supervisors and colleagues
- Strong and supportive faculty community
- **Qualifier – this could be a pro or con, depending on perspective, so I include it on both pro & con lists** Changes & shifts to curriculum and policies based on political pressures involving equity & currently politically correct narratives rather than equality & academic vigor.
cons:
- **Qualifier – this could be a pro or con, depending on perspective, so I include it on both pro & con lists** Changes & shifts to curriculum and policies based on political pressures involving equity & currently politically correct narratives rather than equality & academic vigor.
- SUPER low pay for actual hours required, at least to do your work well & to meet ever-increasing expectations (see in-depth notes below), and including hours before and after contract terms for course set-up and communication/work involving things like late grades, extensions, incompletes, etc. 
- Students have few, if any, basic knowledge or skill requirements, so you are expected to provide a lot of non-academic support (tech help, course/campus navigation, basic English & writing skills, etc.)
- Schedule & expectations don't take holidays, breaks, weekends, etc. into consideration, including answering all communications within 24 hours to their satisfaction.
- NO sick-time, vacation, OT, or affordable benefits available for adjunct.
- Most positions are per-term contracts, so there is ZERO job security.
- Limited contracts are allowed per year to avoid providing benefits.
- Cliquey atmosphere; if you don't participate in extra chats, meetings & webinars, you get less support overall.
- Little-to-no recognition or reward for dedication & performance.
- No consideration for prior experience and little reward for seniority/returning faculty.
- Limited opportunities for higher pay or better positions.
- Expectations go well beyond stated job descriptions & sometimes well outside the scope of typical instructor duties.
- Even if you “meet expectations”, you are open to more obtrusive monitoring through constant objective peer reviews & evaluations.
- High turnover on deans and leads with lots of “restructuring” and “innovating” requiring “retraining” and new expectations, usually with more expected duties for the same pay. 
- Increasingly intensive feedback requirements for instructors on the simplest issues infantilizes students (everything from tech support to where to find uni resources like the library, basic English & writing, etc. - and this is in History courses!).
- Often run as a"client-driven" business rather than an educational institution; students are the clients and instructors are expected to "facilitate" the best experience for each individual to THEIR satisfaction - this dynamic is difficult to maintain if one feels (ethically, personally, morally, professionally, etc,) motivated to actually TEACH.
- Expected to accept & grade late work & large end-of-term projects, then assign final grades within 48 HOURS of the end of the term to ensure funding for the next term (they typically start the next week).

pros:

cons: You do you have to bring your very best every day and make a point to stand out as the organization is very large.

review_title: Great benefits, but selling out as an academic institution
pros: Benefits package is great - Nice insurance package, with 25 days of PTO per year (vacation, sick, etc)
cons: We may be a non-profit, but our goal is no longer education, it's graduation, which of course is an important distinction. While data is crucial to inform decisions of any 21st century operation, in the last two years, it has become all that matters, to the detriment of our students. We are accepting graduate students who aren't ready for graduate level work, and propping them up as best we can to maintain graduation rates, and, lets face it, receiving their guaranteed money through federal financial aid. Side note: COCE employees do not work on the main campus, but instead in a converted mill building downtown. we work in an open cubicle farm, which is supposed to promote collaboration, but can be hugely distracting when trying to crank out 30 calls per day on top of all of the administrative tasks you'll be expected to complete.

review_title: Getting better for UG COCE adjuncts but stil room for improvement

pros: For adjuncts who have taught a set number of courses (15, 25) and who consistently get great teacher ratings now have less demeaning oversight from Team Leads - we get fewer check ins and are trusted to lead our own classes. I personally feel much more ownership in my class with this shift in leadership style. There is also less pressure to promote/pass students who do not or are incapable of completing the work. My intro class students are gaining in caliber and now it is only 1-2 a class that are truly problematic.
cons: Does not reward excellent adjunct instructors for their commitment to the school and the students.

pros: SNHU is a fantastic place to work, it just depends on your dept & role. As an adjunct professor, yes, the hours are long, the pay is little, and the work load is crushing. But Never have I been forced to pass a student or give them a grade they did not deserve unlike other institutions I worked for. Students are online students for a reason, and no, many would not fair well at a traditional college. However, they still deserve the right to gain higher education. As long as professors are willing to put the time to shaping and guiding them. You shouldn't be teaching if your doing it for the money. That's not what it's about. Team leads & dean's actively seek out feedback & provide it. They are always looking for ways to support & improve the quality of educational programming.
cons: I have no real cons. Again, if your teaching for the $$$ then you don't belong in a classroom, virtual or otherwise. Tremendous advancement opportunities at SNHU with continued growth and development. Went from part time to full time after 1 yr. Full amazing benefits with outstanding salary base. Superior support from team leads and directors, and an absolutely fabulous team of coworkers. I have never worked anywhere that promoted their staff and the business like SNHU does. I love it!

pros: Benefits are great and time off is more than fair
cons: Pay is far less than similar roles with other institutions. Micromanaging is ever present day in and day out

pros: Benefits are good, that's it
cons:
I would give zero stars if I could. Every day feels like the whole operation is going to implode because it's run so poorly. The DOE needs to investigate.
First off, everyone is micromanaged within an inch of their lives. Management can see what everyone is doing at all times and uses it against people for being human beings. Need to use the restroom? Better wait until your break even if it's 2 hours away because if you are not tethered to your desk it's a problem. Employees are pressured to work when they are sick or bereaved to make their leaders' numbers look better. Time off is not accounted for when metrics are measured, so everyone is expected to perform the same even if someone was out sick for a week.
Other departments push their responsibilities onto Admission Counselors and when we speak up we are to "assume good intentions" and just take on the work rather than fixing the problem. This has created a culture where everyone knows they can get away with anything and no one does the right thing. Training is a joke - veteran employees provide the training and management does not understand the job so they are incapable of answering questions.
Leadership is comprised of fake people whose actions don't even slightly match up with their words and people who refuse to address issues and instead just deny them forever while they grow. They tells us to "challenge the status quo" and then keep anyone down who could possibly have a positive impact on the status quo because you do not want to change. They prioritize smiling and conforming over actually performing, which is a detriment to the people who sign on to a lifetime of student debt to take classes at the school. They try to curate a culture where people are obsessed with working for them because they know they can't get quality work out of people for such little comparative compensation. It feels like a cult.
Furthermore, they force admission counselors to register students who did NOT give permission to be registered, which has financial consequences if they are dropped for non-participation. They do this to people who have never even spoken with admission counselors on the phone or responded to an email. The admission portal is proving to be a great method to take financial advantage of people.
Don't think admission is a foot in the door to go to another department either, those positions are extremely competitive because everyone wants to leave admission so it's really difficult to go elsewhere.
I'm curious to know what the price was for the "best college to work for" title because if employees were asked we would be nowhere near that list.

pros:
I was an academic advisor for the COCE branch--the branch that works with SNHU's online students.

The pros are the friendly people, from the top down. Granted, you're actually peer-pressured into being friendly and happy all the time; if you don't seem cheerful enough on a given day, you will be pulled aside by your team lead, sometimes with another person to act as a witness, and have your level of happiness questioned and interrogated. The idea is that if everybody acts happy, then the whole place would be happy. Constantly reminded to just "drink the Kool-Aid"--direct quote.

Another plus is that academic advisors get to attend grad school at SNHU for free, while spouse and children get to attend undergrad school for free.
cons: The pay is $13.50, non-negotiable, as of 2016. Also, systemic racism abounds. The largest office is in Manchester, NH, but you won't see any color there. If an ethnic person manages to get hired in order to meet the quota (if you are a woman AND a minority--you're a "twofer"--a two for one deal for them), their team lead will find sneaky ways to push them out by using biasedly collected "proof." For example, all calls with students are recorded. Out of hundreds of calls, there is bound to be one less-than-perfect call. Now, if your team lead wants you out, they would use that one single bad call, out of hundred of successful ones, to submit as a complaint against you. Have enough of those complaints, and you are out. Yet, others who have committed worse errors will get by just fine.

pros: Remote days during bad weather
cons:
Team Leads are a joke. They hire them because they’re driven and focused in they’re ability to schmooze upper management, but they don’t know how to lead a team or support advisors.  Academic Advisors are given more and more work to do—much of it dealing with making sure students don’t lose their financial aid. When good advisors make mistakes, upper management does not stop to consider that maybe this is happening because expectations are unrealistic. Instead good advisors are punished. This is especially true if you cost the school money. Mistakes can be made until it costs SNHU something. 

SNHU accept students who have no place in higher ed. I’m talking about people who can’t even write a complete sentence. And then these students call their advisors and scream at them because they can’t do their homework, and we have to take it.  


This is one of the most anxiety provoking jobs I’ve ever had, and even though I work hard and do my best, I’m just waiting for a day when everything comes crashing down.   If you want a job where you’re doing your best but are always waiting with baited breath for the one day you miss something and everything falls to pieces, this job is for you

pros: You are able to work from home
cons:
1. When you take the pay-rate for the class, and divide it between the number of hours they expect you to work in a week, the pay-rate is abysmal. I would be better off working at Starbucks.

2. The amount of excess and unnecessary work they expect you to do is above and beyond what is required of adjuncts at other colleges.

3. There is no flexibility or support in regards to how you are evaluated. If you are one hour late turning in grades, you will be chastised. It does not matter if your internet was out or not.

4. Team leads are inconsistent. A horrible team leader can make a very difficult experience miserable, and there is little to no recourse for adjunct faculty if a disagreement arises. 

5.  There is no creative control over the materials in the class. You must grade the SNHU assignments using the SNHU rubric whether it makes sense or not.  There is no flexibility or autonomy.

6. Despite the fact that you would expect autonomy in an online adjunct position, there really is none. Prepare for your feedback to be monitored, your grading to be monitored, the amount of time you spend logged in to be monitored etc.

7. The rubrics often make no sense. They allow for students to pass a class even when the student does not know how to spell or use basic punctuation and grammar. The elements graded often do not align to the assignment directions.

review_title: Team Lead but I hate this place
pros: I'm quitting to get a job in private industry--it pays more per hour, plus healthcare and 401k. Seriously, SNHU has made me so sick of the higher education model in the US right now, I'd rather take my graduate degree and do anything else at a company that appreciates my abilities and experience. Even though SNHU deans expect 40+ hours of work a week between teaching and Team Lead duties, the pay does not go higher than $25k--and, let me repeat, you are expected to work at a full-time rate with complete accountability for all your actions, attendance at innumerable meetings, and constant oversight of every letter you type into classes and on faculty evaluations. This is the worst job I've ever had in higher education, and I've taught at some really shady places.
cons: SNHU expects Team Leads and faculty to work endlessly with mediocre students and a so-so curriculum. Honestly, with the "soft" quality of the degrees and the low expectations on students, I don't know how SNHU is cooking the books on its gainful employment numbers. Students can turn in ANY quality of work, ANY time they want in the term, and get a passing grade--the expectations on faculty are clear, passed down from on high, that ANY student work is PASSING student work. SNHU is a degree mill: nothing more, nothing less.

pros: Great benefits, talented co-workers, and boundless opportunities to recreate the wheel. The department is relatively small, so there are still a lot of opportunities to evolve our level of support for our students. We have segmented the department to address different areas of need and have seen some successes from it. Co-workers feel like family. It's great to have people genuinely concerned for your well-being.
cons: Management, unrealistic goals and blatant favoritism are the major issues within the department. If you voice a concern and management does not agree, you will be viewed as a "cancer" on the team. Growth is not possible unless you are a part of the in-group, which is sad because management appears to be so oblivious to the vibe and ultimately finds excuses as to why turnover is high instead of listening to staff. Management used to hire based on talent and experience, but that is no longer the case, which could be another reason why people keep leaving the department. Setting unrealistic goals for the departmental segments is not motivating. Data collected, does not support the goals that are put in place for the department, which is confusing to the staff members expected to meet them.

review_title: A good place to work with great benefits
pros: The people are amazing and there are some opportunities for growth (but a lot of competition). Great health benefits and the option to work remotely 2 days per week for some positions. The mission, vision and values as well as CEO statements are on point. Some students are very pleasant to work with and appreciative of your help which makes it rewarding.
cons: There is a good amount of micromanagement. Weekly one on one meetings with your supervisor and quality reviews where they scrutinize your caseload and outreach to students. The job is a lot more data-focused and salesy than I expected. Students blow us off over and over and we are still expected to develop a relationship with them. Since there are no admission requirements, some of the students you work with have a very low academic level and really struggle in college courses, which can be a challenge. Some students are verbally abusive (we have behavioral expectations and they may receive a warning but nothing solid ever comes of it),  and we still have to provide customer service to some very difficult and demanding students. The parking is terrible, you are assigned at parking garages all over the city and shuttled in (at unreliable time intervals) making your commute 15-20 minutes longer.

pros: Coming from a fairly large and established company I was in an extreme state of culture shock, at first I could not believe that a business could operate this way. After a year or so the culture grew on me briefly be very quickly my original opinion returned. I suppose if you right out of college this is a great first experience, however if you ever leave SNHU and join the real corporate world you will be extremely unprepared for corporate America. Health insurance is cheap, other than that benefits are just ok if you are not salaried.
cons:
Where to begin, well most importantly - this company does not conduct background checks. Yup, there are people employed who have serious criminal records. I'm not quite sure the reasoning behind this, if I had to guess it would just put a damper on their "can you start tomorrow?" Hiring process.  

The online school, COCE drives this business and knows it. Any other supporting business unit to the school or university appears to recieve very little investment causing one department growth to just balloon while everyone else suffers. Sooner or later something is going to burst and business will take a sharp decline.

Third, Online adjunct are extremely under appreciated and it's impossible for a student to fail.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty Member (Online) in Manchester, NH
pros: Online teaching with flexibility of location and login times.  Courses are standardized, so the university provides content and faculty supplement it, as well as grade student assignments.  Opportunities for professional development.
cons: In my 5+ years of teaching for SNHU, the responsibilities and expectations for faculty members, as well as course caps, have steadily increased, while the salary has remained almost constant.  Team Leads are embedded in courses and monitor every move an instructor makes.  The feedback that faculty must provide to students is extensive and detailed, yet SNHU offers limited guidance on its expectations.  More often than not, faculty members are "dinged" for not providing enough detailed feedback, but accolades for good work are rarely given.  Academic Advisors view themselves as "customer service professionals" and regularly push for unreasonable exemptions and exceptions for their advisees.  The workload for faculty is extreme; the university expects almost full-time output for a single course.  Students are woefully underprepared for coursework.  While there are some exceptional students, the vast majority are not capable of completing a degree program at a traditional university.

review_title: Southern New Hampshire University is a great college to work for!
pros: The one-team mentality and drive to do the right thing every time makes SNHU stand out from the competition!
cons: I can't think of any cons!

pros: I've had various roles at SNHU from adjunct to team lead.  I've found that most of my correspondence with team mates was supportive and friendly.
cons:
Most of these reviews hit the nail on the head.  I've been teaching here for 7 years and have never received a raise.  I make what a new adjunct makes and regularly get micromanaged by Team Leads who I've never heard of nor met which makes me think they are new.  This is what happens when there is no upward mobility for these positions.  Class sizes exploded within the last year.  I used to have 20 students average, now it's 27-30.  

Despite no pay increase and larger class sizes, the expectations on feedback are the same.  The feedback standard is "substantive and detailed."  Can you say moving target?  What this usually amounts to is that teachers have to write more words in feedback than is required on many of the student's assignments!  If only we were allowed to scrutinize the students the same way that adjuncts are scrutinized, then we'd be getting somewhere.  

SNHU went from being a reputable university that I would recommend to becoming the next University of Phoenix.

pros: I have worked at other jobs throughout my work career, however, I have never worked in an environment such as this one!  The training is intensive and detailed, the follow up training includes one-to-one's, mentoring and the full support of other veteran advisors on the team. The atmosphere is supportive, inclusive, friendly and overall inviting. Our leaders have an open-door policy that allow us to just come in and talk, ask questions and simply have conversations about whatever is on our minds at the time. Whenever I don't know something, I am not made to feel like "you should know this by now" - it's more like "ask ..... they can help you with that" or "here is where you can find this or that". I am also encouraged to better myself on a professional level. I have never worked at a company that not only provided my me with the tools to improve myself but set me up for success by offering me many opportunities  to learn and aspire to move up within the institution.
cons: The only "con" the I can think of is wanting one more "remote" day but other than that, I am totally excited about working for SNHU and hope to be here for many, many years to come.

job_title: Adjunct Online Instructor in Saint Paul, MN
pros: The school is excellent in really reaching out to its students.  It clearly wants them to succeed, and makes every effort to help them.  The first line supervisors seem to be good as well, and I've only had useful feedback from them.  As a properly regionally accredited institution it is very much a "real" college, and I'm proud to work here.  For those looking at more academic careers (which are fewer all the time) this certainly gives experience and keeps one active in their field.  It's also fun.
cons: Salary is a bit low with few upward bumps possible.  Some training is available but its pretty basic.  Encouraging students to keep to timetables can be as much an art as a science, but most of them get it pretty fast.  As both a plus and a minus, sometimes they open up more about their personal problems than they would face to face, but one can listen and recommend the school's counseling section.  In some ways you are more in their lives than if just in a classroom!

pros: I enjoyed how coworkers embrace the mission and vision of the school. I work at COCE, and there are a lot of wonderful people here. There is a great team environment, especially within all of the smaller teams that we have. Our direct managers are wonderful. This may be the most supportive environment I have ever worked in. Also, there are excellent opportunities for growth. The company is an exciting place to work as a whole.
cons: Depending on what department you are in, you could have quite a different experience. Admissions is an uncredibly high stress environment, but they also have a lot of fun. Advising is also another high stress department, and you see a lot of forced fun that employees try to be enthusiastic about. Academics is quite busy, but not with the intesity of the other bigger departments. It is less of the super enthusiastic environment and a little more subdued. Also, because it is a nonprofit, salaries aren't very competitive.

pros: I can work from home.  I make my own hours.  I love teaching.  This income supplements my other teaching job.
cons: It’s a lot of handholding.  I’m not saying the students don’t get a quality education, but the school really does make it too easy for them to pass.  These are adults and yet so many of them coast through the class and end up with a B when their effort was minimal.  I agree completely with the reviews that mentioned that we are expected to give pages of feedback when the assignment was like two paragraphs.  Then you will get the occasional student that makes you wanna blow your brains out, but you HAVE to kiss their butts.  I just had one last semester and every time I saw her name in my inbox I wanted to scream.

job_title: Sales Representative, Admission Department in Manchester, NH
pros: There’s a five word minimum for this section.
cons:
As a former employee, I can’t sit here and let others reading these reviews think for one second that the majority of the positive ones are real. Don’t get me wrong - some are genuine. But make no mistake, they are few and far between. 

It’s been confirmed by friends I have still stuck in this hell hole that management incentivizes employees to post positive reviews in an attempt to balance out the negative ones and improve their rating on Glassdoor. This is blatantly obvious by the quality of the two types of reviews - just look at them. The negative ones have substance and actually say something. The positives? All fluff. Less than one sentence per section for most of them. 

Please, please, please everyone, see this for what it is: first and foremost, complete dishonesty and deception. Second, management assuming you, the potential employee, are stupid enough to not see through such a paper-thin guise. BEFORE YOU EVEN WORK FOR THEM they are condescending to you. My God.

Stay far, far away from this place. They take advantage of employees and students alike. SNHU is a joke in the realm of higher ed and their “degrees” are even less meaningless. There is no way an investigation by the DOE isn’t looming. For your own sake, don’t involve yourself in that.

pros: Some of the courses are well-designed.  Many of the students are excellent.  The courses are built out thoroughly; the processes and procedures are well-developed.
cons: The faculty are micro-managed by "Team Leads" who possess just some tangential knowledge about a class yet are empowered to evaluate the faculty member's grasp of it.  Thus evaluations are only about the quantity of work you do and not the quality.  Just as much emphasis is placed on making unique comments to each student about one discussion post worth less than half a percent of the grade as on giving unique comments on major projects worth 20 percent of the grade--thus faculty are rated poorly for "substandard" performance on meaningless things.  The whole focus is "on the metrics" and not on the meaning. The micromanagement is maddening, inefficient, and unproductive.

review_title: Excellent Distance Learning for Instructors at University
pros: One of SNHU's distinguishing characteristics is not only its non-profit and independent nature, with an attractive physical campus in Manchester, NH, but also its professional training program for new adjunct faculty to instruct in distance learning, which is highly relevant in today's COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on higher education. With many universities struggling to adapt to the new on-line educational environment, SNHU is a veteran practitioner in distance learning with a robust portal. Apparently, it's also one of the very few universities in the U.S. to devote 3 weeks to rigorously train its new adjunct faculty in the pedagogy of instruction and in how to use its distance learning portal for instruction - and to pay the instructors to participate in the training. A cohort of adjunct faculty participated in my training program, which was led by a terrific faculty leader. We were graded in our assignments, so the quality of participation was very high. The course I was assigned is pedagogically rigorous and of a high standard. Overall, from the perspective of a new adjunct faculty, the communication from the administration to the faculty is regular, helpful, and friendly. I highly recommend SNHU as a high quality distance learning higher education university.
cons: No cons - only positives.

pros: They have work available but that's probably because they go through staff all the time as no one sticks around long unless they're desperate.
cons: Team leads micromanage. Workload is tremendous. Classroom sizes are too large. Grading is too extensive, too detailed and overwhelming. Nearly all students get As and Bs. They bend over backwards for students and not at all for teachers. This place is like a drive up window. Place your order for a diploma and an helpful teacher will do anything to keep you satisfied and keep your money coming in. Thats because they have management watching every single then they do. There's no spellchecker it the grading area to top it off. The pay is lousy when you tally up the hours. If students complain, they do anything to render it and more. If teachers complain, they are disregarded. This place sucks to work for. It's nothing more than a machine. If you work there, you are oiling it. If you are going to school there, you are supporting it and not getting an honest grade, due to the skew of the rubrics and the teachers having to grade high.  Find another place to go work or get an education. Not disgruntled. Just honest.
