-Do not listen to concerns about workload
-Say they are for work-life balance, but this has decreased substantially as the university has grown in the last 5 years
-The size of the university can contribute to problems for movement up in the university because it is hard to stand out

pros: I really enjoy working with the adult learners. I enjoy the discussions. Many of the students are as proud as you see on those (albeit sometimes annoying) commercials.
cons: SO much grading. We are expected to be chained to the general comments forum and our emails all the time. Grades have to be done in 1 week's time, which wouldn't be bad except the classes are so big and the grading is so detailed that I feel like I do nothing but grade. This is problematic because a) we are teachers, not grading machines and b) it takes away from meaningfully contributing to the discussions which we have to do along with grading. There is a SUBSTANTIAL amount of micromanagement by team leads who use the term "best practices" to basically say, "we're not telling you that you'd better do something our way, but you had better do it our way." There is just way too much work for the very little pay you get.

review_title: If you like sales jobs, go for it.
pros:
Nice people
Half off Starbucks. Good caf. food
Fair wages
Excellent benefits 
Free education for their employees
The team leaders try to make things fun for the staff
cons:
Frequent changes (seating, curriculum, policies)
Competitive job nature. Sometimes feel like you're not doing well because you are put against others 
Glorified sales/customer service job.
Boring to be stuck at your desk and on the phone all day (I was happy to have meetings so I could get up!)

review_title: SNHU is a top-notch University that offers challenging academic programs
pros:
They are a traditional University that offers challenging academic programs on-campus (traditional), online, as well as hybrid courses.

Employers respect SNHU graduates, since they know SNHU students are well educated by the time they graduate.  

SNHU students with good GPA's have to work hard for their grades.
cons:
The school is very expensive.  

Some of the adjuncts in the online department are absolutely terrible and should not be allowed to teach. In addition, online instructors need to engage students more than they do. Many times students fail their classes online, because they do not get help from the instructors. 

Finally, SNHU TV ads are damaging the school's brand. Their ads make them look like the University of Phoenix or like some other online school. SHNU is NOT an online school; they need to do a better job with their TV ads.

review_title: SNHU will demand your very best
pros: They are very student centered, they offer a lot of training webinars for their faculty, and they support their faculty very well - you know your team leads and deans and are encouraged to contact them.
cons: They are serious about demanding your dedication.  You have to work every single day; there are no weekends or holidays if you work for SNHU.  If you need a vacation, you have to take an entire 8 week term off, as the school runs year round. With all the required webinars and the many daily emails to which you have to respond or do whatever is directed, in addition to grading as many as 60 student papers a week and responding to your students, you can start to feel hounded.

review_title: Good initially, until you learn what the company's real objectives are.
pros: Great benefits, lots of open positions
cons:
This is in reference to the COCE (online and continuing ed) part of the school, which is the vast majority of the company.

The stated objectives all promote student success, but they don't want to actually train or challenge students.  They actively phased out student help programs while literally saying the opposite.  The advising department is managed at a high level by individuals with inaddequite education, experiences, and skills; they tend to promote of personal preference.  The VIP of that department actively browses the net on her iphone while in interviews, many of which she is late for.

More concerning is the firing practices, which actually consist of asking high and mid level employees to leave with minimal severance, and withholding pay unless they sign a non-standard and brutal non-disclosure agreement.  I personally am aware of at least one discriminatory firing lawsuit that amounted to a very large payout on their part.

I'd suggest potential applicants looking for a career position with a school look elsewhere; it really is a disheartening and potentially dangerous career move.

pros: Great people and environment, recommend Portsmouth over the Manchester location (smaller and more tight-knit), lots of opportunities for growth (if you transition to Manchester), terrific benefits, good entry level job to build skills in customer service, sales and higher ed
cons: Some incompetent Team Leads can make the job frustrating, Admission is by far the one of the most stressful departments to work in, yet the pay does not reflect that, takes short time to become competent at the job and then it just becomes repetitive, high turn over due to burnout, some "all hands on deck" hours meaning they are "voluntary" overtime hours but you are pressured into staying and it reflects poorly on you if you do not

review_title: Great place to work, however, adjunct graduate faculty pay needs increased
pros: I've been working for SNHU for over three years as an adjunct professor teaching graduate level courses within my professional field. It is a great place to work with the exception of pay.
cons: Undergraduate faculty members receive $275 per week per course while graduate faculty who typically have PhDs receive $227 per week per course.  An undergraduate faculty member will earn $13,200 per year for teaching one course year round.  A graduate faculty member will receive $10,000 per year for teaching one course year round.  Other universities pay a higher income to those with terminal degrees, however, SNHU does just the opposite.  They justify this policy by stating that there were fewer students in graduate courses, however, that just isn't the case now.  The last six courses I've taught were full with 25 students in each.

pros: The ability to work from home.
cons: Inconsistent with leads who do not have a clear understanding of the course assigned to them as leaders. Pay is sub par. Expect adjunct to cater to students. Students do not understand the basic premise around APA standards. An adjunct is not holding students accountable. Students are not accountable truthfully to missed assignments. The grading standards are not equivalent to the assignments. Did I say the pay is very low considering the amount of time you engage with the students? $2500 a quarter. If you work exactly 10 hours a week, that is $250 before taxes. Ph.D. adjuncts are paid the same as master level adjuncts in the online platform.

pros: Since joining almost one year ago, I have not only felt so welcome by the amazing SNHU community, but have felt so supported by my leadership, team, and the organization via benefits, development, and opportunities to contribute to positive initiatives involving the Manchester community and our internal community.  Each department or business unit can be unique with their remote policies and team dynamic understandably, but I have found that any form of leadership I have connected with are very open to new ideas around improving efficiency and productivity. SNHU listens. I have witnessed my colleagues, who are not in positions of management, make huge positive impacts to our policies and procedures just by sharing an idea. It is so empowering to truly feel heard and valued.
cons: I will share that any cons I've experienced have been heard and action steps have been taken to improve. SNHU takes an anonymous survey each month and I can share that from an HR standpoint, every single concern is addressed and an action plan is created, then shared with the community.

pros: Great benefits, and a lot of great people in the trenches. 403b retirement/pension, insurance plan, discounts, free "education". Those are the perks.
cons: This place is nothing but a diploma mill and smoke and mirrors. COCE runs like a corporation. Higher management is terrible and treats the people with little or no respect. The work culture is horrible.  I watched my "has-been" of an inept boss fire 4 people because she couldn't give them good or even the correct direction. And when her projects failed she blamed them and off they went. I've also seen higher management take credit for work they had no part in, and have even gone as far as taking credit for work that belonged to other companies. They're literally guilty of stealing ideas. They know nothing of the golden rule.

pros: I have been with COCE Advising for just under three years, and this is one of the best jobs I have ever had. The culture within the office makes the job. Within the three years I have worked here, I have gained many friendships that will last for years to come. On top of the culture, the job itself is very rewarding. Working with students, you are able to follow their progress, and help them to their goal of graduating by motivating them and being their support team. The benefits of this job are also amazing. From the health insurance plans to their tuition reimbursement program, they offer almost everything. The president of the university is very down to earth, and is always looking to improve the organization.
cons: Change is a constant in the office. If this is something that you do not do well with, this is not the job for you. The change is frequent, but necessary to keep up with the ever-changing industry,

review_title: What a great opportunity to grow!
pros: The culture here with SNHU is nothing like anything I've experienced in my career. While other organizations talk a big game with inclusion, culture and employee development, SNHU delivers on all fronts. The benefits are amazing, with 5 weeks PTO, Heath Benefits (low premium / low delectable plans), 9% employer  retirement contribution every year (vested in 3) and of course, low cost education offerings for myself and family. It's hard to compete with a total rewards and package that they offer, even if the comp structure is a little lower than what you might see in a Corp / Fortune 500...etc, but that's to be expected within Higher Ed and the Non-Profit sector.
cons: While no employer is perfect, I have very little in the way of Con's at this time but can say that SNHU is different, and they are proving it every day with tenured and new employees alike!

review_title: Excellent Place to be Adjunct Instructor
job_title: Adjunct Faculty Nursing Program in Remote, OR
pros:
Instructors are supported.
Team Leads are there for you and help keep you on task.  
No mystery about expectations, there is a written guide on what to do when.
HR was great during interview and hiring process.  Many other colleges were just TERRIBLE and incompetent
I also had opportunity to interview for FT position.  They were very transparent about expectations and it would have been too much for me at this time.  I appreciated their professionalism.
cons:
Most students are serious, but some take on more than they can handle, thinking 'online education is easier'...it's not.  It's just more flexible.
Usually, there are maybe 2 or 3 students per term you are chasing after for work.  SNHU does support you in enforcing late policy if it applies and student does not ask for extension prior to due date.

pros: Good part time job. Flexible hours.
cons: Pay is not good based on the expectations. Even if you get good reviews for term after term, you cannot depend on getting a teaching assignment. It is very inconsistent. Raises are given after 15 and 20 terms of teaching and as you reach that level, you receive less assignments. People at McDonalds make more than the adjuncts. The full time staff is so worried about their jobs that they do not help the adjuncts at all, but offer platitudes. The team lead program is a joke and the advice is inconsistent. It is a very discouraging job but  colleges offer few tenured positions these days as they do not want to pay benefits.

pros:
I loved working at SNHU. It's a very supportive culture and the team-mentality is very strong. Students, administrators, and faculty are all very excited about education and their personal roles. 
Workload varied with the term starts and ends, but being part of a great team meant that we were all encouraging one another throughout the busy sections. They have a great system for communication and people are very responsive to emails and messages! Higher level management responded to my questions within an hour or so on more than one occasion.
cons: I didn't have any complaints here, so I'll just pass along what I heard from other people. Adjunct professors said that for their workload, they did not get paid nearly enough to actually meet the demands of their classes. Some advisors said that they had an unbalanced workload-- some were responsible for a lot of student while others didn't have enough.

job_title: Adjunct English Instructor in Manchester, NH
pros:
Strong organization
Effective communication
Close attention to detail 
Commitment to students 
Intentional training and support
cons:
Faulty course design
Illogical rubrics
Stringent feedback demands using rubrics
Focus mainly on perceived deficiencies
Over-investment in outlying negative student evaluations

review_title: Sales, I mean, Admission Counselor- Changing Lives!
pros: Great benefits- health and PTO
cons: This place sucked my soul dry in the name of changing lives at a nonprofit.  When I started, the admission department was 30 people.  When I left, it was over 200.  The culture became all about registration numbers.  Overtime every two months wasn't mandatory, but if you didn't take part, you were deemed to not care about your job or your students, and had no future.   This applied even if you had taken care of all of your students.  If you had questions about policy or practices, you were seen as confrontational, no matter how polite or respectful you were in your questions.  Promotion decisions are made solely on how good you are at sucking up to a highly unethical management team.  Upper management berated and bullied people with serious medical conditions to pressure them to quit.  The actuality of this place does not at all line up with the supposed mission of the university.  The culture is terminally toxic, and the pay does not balance out for the work.

pros: Able to earn extra income from home. Gain college level teaching experience (if needed.)
cons:
The pay seems good at first, but the workload for just one class is too much. It may depend on the class or department. However I taught in two different departments and both were about the same. Both of my team leads gave constant critique on everything; mostly concerning quantity not quality: longer this, longer that, more, more, more. I agree feedback is important, but more isn't always necessary or better. It just takes more time.
Both team leads I worked under had little to no understanding of the subject material so a lot of time feedback was mistaken and I had to spend more time explaining myself.
Some students should not have been admitted and are not ready for college level work. I was often pressured to keep working with such students which only sets them up for failure.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty/Subject Matter Expert [SME] in Baltimore, MD
pros: There are so many levels of support designed to help both students and faculty succeed at this institution.  The people are amazing! They do not give grades away as some other reviewers insinuate.  The faculty and advisers really work with students to help them succeed. They have won many well-deserved awards such as #1 Most Innovative Schools for the 2017 cycle of U.S. News and World Report Best Colleges for "most innovative improvements in terms of curriculum, faculty, students, campus life, technology or facilities."
cons: It is always difficult when a student earns a failing grade after you've offered them every opportunity to succeed.  This disappointment is no different at SNHU than any other institution.  No cons specific to this institution.  As another reviewer stated, time management is paramount for adjunct faculty.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in South Hooksett, NH
pros: The pay is relatively good for a three-credit course, and class sizes are reasonable.
cons: All of the course content is canned. While this sounds like an easier course due to not having to create new materials, you will very quickly found out that none of the assignments require any rigor. If you deviate from their grading system (the students can get an A, B, or F on individual assignments, but they won't tell you this upfront), you will get your hands smacked for grading inappropriately. I'm sorry, though: A student who deserves a D shouldn't automatically get a B. Also, expect that you'll be getting emails from the people who watch everything you do during the week. Finally, don't expect to be able to transfer your typical post-secondary teaching at this institution; rather, expect to be a grader of assignments, a responder to emails, a writer of weekly announcements, and ultimately part of the problem with declining standards and accountability at the post-secondary level.

review_title: Stressful job, strict layout and high expectations.
job_title: Financial Aid Counselor in Manchester, NH
pros: Great benefits, good EAP program, kind co-workers
cons: It is honestly impossible to work here at this possible. During training, there were many people that quit and those that didnt, were crying at the stress level. This job is not easy and the pay is terrible. $16 an hour is terrible for the amount of work this job takes. Even the smartest person could not complete this training without complete confusion/frustration . When I understood how to do this job, I had no assistance. I got in so much trouble for missing work with medical concerns. I felt so lost here and Team Leads are strict and not easy to approach regarding personal matters. I understand striving for excellence but it seems like SNHU strives for perfection and no human can do this. Also, everyone here seems like they were brainwashed about how great SNHU is and its odd for sure. I hate the position I am in and wanted to transfer but i was informed that I could not until 9 months at my current position. Most weeks are 5-6 days with long hours and late hours too.

job_title: Adjunct Instructor Political Science in Saint Louis, MO
pros: It does pay something to me.
cons: Lots of mindless and tedious grading. That takes up the bulk of my work. I am expected to write a paragraph for each student, each week evaluating their discussion board posts. I suspect when students get 100%, they don’t even read the feedback, anyway. And there is zero autonomy. Administration pokes around your class, ensuring you are writing a paragraph, for each student, for each discussion. The quality of students is low. This makes my job harder because most of the essays are poorly written. I teach political science, but a lot of my time is spent as a writing instructor. Some of the essays are so poorly written, they are hard to read. I make about $1,000 a month. In reality, you are better working as a tutor for $30 an hour, if you can.

pros: Amazing health benefits, pension and PTO. Plenty of room for growth and love working with students. Typically a fun atmosphere with many achievement celebrations.
cons: SNHU seems to be having an identity crisis and is trying too hard to maximize admission of new students. Rather than listening and understanding the needs of a student and ensuring that they are a good fit, SNHU is beginning to look the other way to make sure the student can start school as soon as possible without all the facts. Many students are pushed to starting school whether they are prepared for it or not.

review_title: Excellent Employer - Great benefits, but less than great pay
pros: The benefits at SNHU are second to none. Extremely cheap medical, vision, and dental and they're actually good benefits. The tuition benefit is also amazing, allowing the employee or a direct dependent of the employee to go to school for free.
cons: Unfortunately the pay is not something to write home about. Although the benefits are fantastic, it's difficult to look around at other jobs similar to what you're doing and see that you're not making nearly as much. Since it's non-profit, there's also no 401k program. This is somewhat remedied by the 401a that's offered (9% of salary per year, fully vested after three BUSINESS years which starts in September...not actual working years)

pros: Great insurance benefits, old-fashioned pension plan, generous vacation time
cons:
Very low pay, salaries starting in the 30's even with experience.
Poor management - many employees roles' and responsibilities are unclear.
Very clicque-y - if you are not below the age of 35, you are left behind and provided  less opportunities.
Bullying by exclusion, false accusations and distorting the facts. Defend yourself, and you are ostracized.
Not allowed to use the funds provided for employee personal growth-i.e. was denied request for off-site workshops. There was always an excuse.
Some are provided the maximum opportunities, while others are not. HR will not help with this.
Dead end job.
Working conditions-deplorable bathrooms with a ridiculous locked door policy, leaking ceilings, bat droppings on desks, dusty and smelly, freezing in the winter, but not allowed to use space heaters because the electrical system can't handle it.
School reputation is suffering- degree mill.

review_title: Supportive work environment with great benefits
pros: Great culture, EXCELLENT benefits, fair time off, many roles have flexibility with occasional work from home, supportive environment, free tuition for employees and tuition benefits for immediate family, sense that the work you do makes a positive impact on people's lives
cons: There are annual "cost-of-living" increases, but it's difficult to earn performance-based incentives and the pay is sometimes a little lower than in the private sector; organization is getting a little less flat (as it grows) and there is a sense that they are diversifying too fast and without listening to those on the ground who really understand impact.

pros: good pay, good benefits, good PTO
cons:
-most team leads get promoted only having 1 year of experience, do not know how to manage. 
-lots of micromanaging, every week you meet 1 on 1 with team lead to go through your students and listen to your calls, even if you are doing well with numbers
- new hires have horrible hours 
- you have to wear a headphone all the time (per some team leads) and on ready to take calls most of the day. you only get 2 hours of off phone time. so during the hours you have to be on ready, if you switch to off ready to go to the bathroom, team leads can see it and will tell you to be on ready.

pros: Flexible hours, coworkers are all around your own age (if you're just out of college), if you attempt to not care too much about the job then you can probably succeed.
cons: Too much politicking, policies change without notice, gossip, no room for growth, you're told to do what they say and not ask questions, you're told what to say before meetings, RANK means EVERYTHING.

job_title: Assistant Director in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Flexible schedule, provided technology and training, wrote my own job description
cons: Low pay, incompetent, unethical leadership. Worked for someone who paid her own husband and spouses of people who worked for her. Jobs were never posted but people were paid. Since leaving the company, I have learned she has been promoted, proving how incompetent her supervisor and his supervisor must be; must be for saving money she should have paid to her employees and paying her husband instead. You would think that a non-profit would have a better sense of where money is going.

review_title: Data-driven, but they make the #'s say what they want
pros: Great benefits, and okay pay. If you play the game and make the right friends, you've got a golden ticket. Office culture used to be great, and they claim that they're driven by the numbers...
cons: Except they manipulate the numbers to match what they want to hear. And god help you if you speak up and disagree with any leadership. They say they want to hear your ideas, but only if they echo their own. Not a good place long-term for people who truly want to innovate and grow.

job_title: Information Technology Solutions in Manchester, NH
pros: There is a reason that SNHU has been ranked in the top 10 of Great Colleges to Work For. The atmosphere is fun, engaging, relaxed, and many more. There are amazing benefits that other places just cannot compete.
cons: Within certain departments, it is very difficult to be promoted from within. There is a mentality, specifically in the department that I work in, that "why would we promote employees who know the culture of the University but may need a little training in some areas of a job function, when we can hire from external candidates that know what already know what they are doing." I can't that is everyone's mentality, but it has been stated from those that are the ultimately say yes or no on a candidate. This may not be in all departments, but for my current one, it has left a discouraging mark on those that would like to move up within the University.

review_title: Best Place to Work in New Hampshire
pros: The most important things about SNHU is the people. This is an incredibly mission driven organization, and that characteristic can be felt with everyone you work with. The benefits are great with time off being the most significant destination from other employers (starting at 5 weeks!).  For those that want to go back to school, tuition is completely covered by SNHU, as well as for dependants,  which is another great bonus you don't get anywhere else. Both environments, On Campus or the Millyard, are great working environments if you are lucky enough to work here!
cons: Comparative to the corporate world the sarlies will be less, I took a pay cut to be here, but the work is so rewarding.

job_title: Online Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros: The people that I worked with were very nice. I will miss them but cannot stand one more semester working with this college.
cons: I must agree with many other adjuncts on this forum that the amount of work expected from adjuncts at this college is absurd.  The class count at 28 along with the poor instructions of the many assignments to students that are poorly prepared to understand these instructions, let alone complete the assignments to any positive standard, translates to adjuncts spending countless hours grading and grading and grading.  Many students have to redo their assignments as they didn't understand the directions in the first place which means instructors have go back and grade them once they are submitted which could e 3-4 weeks later in the semester.

pros: SNHU is a place that is just as excited to try out new ideas as I am. They do not look down on change and instead are always looking on how best to run the school and how to serve both the student and the employee. The atmosphere is bright and energetic and everyone is willing to help others out.
cons: The food in the cafeteria could be better quality and the lighting in some parts of the building are a bit too dark. How we interact with our students can sometimes be too coddling.

pros: I worked for the College of Online and Continuing Education, which is part of, but separate from, the campus institution.  COCE had a great work environment -- good training and extensive professional development opportunities.  There's a conscientious effort to keep lines of communication open and to help employees create a good work/life balance.  The university is very dedicated to its mission and works to keep that vision at the forefront of all that it does.
cons: COCE has been experiencing tremendous growth, so there's constant change and there have been some bumps in the road in terms of dealing with the need for a corporate mentality within the field of higher education.

pros: SNHU is a great institution. They offer support for whatever need you have. Consistent pay, well-paid, 8-week terms, the people @ SNHU are exceptionally accommodating.
cons: If you have an aversion to being micro-managed, you will have a difficult time adjusting to the culture at SNHU. Remember when Customer Service was still a thing and the customer was always right? At SNHU the student is always right, and it is your job to make sure they feel that way. There will be no disapproving tones, regardless of how many times you have told the student two sentences do not a paragraph make, nor is a paragraph synonymous with a page.

pros: Work/life balance, benefits, coworkers, work from home, positive office atmosphere, President LeBlanc is terrific
cons: Advising is becoming more and more like a sales job - we are taught very little about the courses and programs but the emphasis on collecting registrations is profound. Advisors’ caseloads are large and increased outreach expectations mean there isn’t much time for meaningful conversations. Changes happen so rapidly that there was no time for a proper testing period on the change before it. Emphasis on customer service has gone so far that the job resembles that of a call center representative. Call count is one of the few measurables in the job regardless of the fact that the position requires a tremendous amount of administrative work off the phones.

review_title: Don’t waste your time working here!!
job_title: Admission Counselor II in Manchester, NH
pros: You work with amazing people on your team but management is a joke. If they don’t like you they will push you out of the company even if you are good at your job. All about numbers and not about the “student”. If you want to change lives do it somewhere else. I’ve worked there for years and it’s been just down hill.
cons: Management will micromanage you and watch everything you do. Probably the worst part of the job is everything you do is recorded so if you are a minute off trust me except a message. Also don’t bother working here if you are five minutes late it counts as a call out. Also don’t try to take your vacations near a term start that’s not allowed and if you go on vacation expect it to be looked down upon.

pros: The benefits, the people I work with and interact with across departments, & the overall  mission of the school. Summer hours has been wonderful.
cons: Not just open concept seating, but how huge and warehouse-like the open space is. Taking away the 30 min early on a Friday is a disappointment.

job_title: Online Adjunct Professor in Manchester, NH
pros:
If you teach the same class over and over, the workload is manageable. 
 Fairly good pay for a short adjuncting gig. 
 Good support and resources from team leads, deans, etc.
cons:
Too many students per class makes grading unreasonable.
 They make changes to your class and don't inform you so you are surprised by them. 
 They completely overhauled my course, making many improvements but tripling my workload. 
 Many of the people adjuncting for this university aren't experts in the field they are teaching.

review_title: Wonderful culture, amazing benefits, fulfilling work
pros:
SNHU does an excellent job of creating a culture that encourages positivity, collaboration, and constant growth. From day one, I felt as though my opinions and suggestions really mattered and could have an impact on my team.

The work is meaningful and enjoyable. It strikes an excellent balance between coaching/supporting learners and organizational duties like course planning and database management. This job has sharpened my ability to multitask, enhanced my personal communication skills, and improved my ability to organize with intention.

It doesn't hurt that the benefits are excellent either, plus you get free Masters level courses!
cons: The evening shifts can be a bit taxing, especially if you have a long commute (currently, shuttle rides to parking lots add about 20-30 min to my already 45 min drive), but they're building a parking garage to address this concern.

pros:
- Respectful and hardworking students
- Work-flow has been consistent lately
- Training crops up every few months to keep reviewers in-the-know
- Good pay! Even with part-time work, the job provides livable wages
cons:
- Even if you're one second over the allotted work time, management gets their tinsel in a tangle
- Inconsistent lead reviewers. One lead will train you one way while another undermines that one and suggests everything learned during training is wrong
- Some lead reviewers are on power trips and will make sure they make a job difficult for some tutors and reviewers
- Some lead reviewers are unclear about expectations

pros:
Love the flexibility from working at home. 
The students are typically good (at Graduate level)
Get courses each term
cons:
The courses are outdated -they are not spending the money to redesign or add new material. 
Lack of support for the staff (yet a lot for the students)
There is no balance you are paid for 10 hours a week but work closer to 20-25

pros: A little extra cash (emphasis on little, considering the work load)
cons:
I agree with many of the downsides mentioned in other reviews:
- Micromanaging from team leads is ridiculous. You do realize we have degrees, right? If you don't trust our skills, perhaps you shouldn't hire us.
- Watered down curriculum. The assignments are embarrassing. Many of the assignments don't relate to the course title! It is ridiculous that they have so many assignments that ask about feelings and goals. They are basically selling degrees.
- The amount of grading is ridiculous.
- The late policy is a joke. You can submit late work up to the last day of class. How does that prepare anyone for the real world? On top of that, each week we have to beg students to submit the late work.

pros:
If you are a young employee- recent college grad- working for the College of Online and Continuing Education (COCE) will help you to gain experience. Just make sure you have a clear exit plan, including how to transition from online higher ed to traditional higher ed. 

Otherwise, don't believe the hype.
cons:
COCE is a profit-driven cult. While COCE may portray itself to be the Statue of Liberty for non-traditional students, the organization's non-profit mission has been lost. COCE is a corporate cash cow. Predatory admissions tactics that take advantage of prospective students- many of whom are not qualified for even the most watered down version of college- have driven growth to 80K enrollment with projected revenue over $500 million. An obscene percentage of this revenue is spent not on strengthening programs and services, but glitzy national advertising. 

The name of the game is scale and persistence, but the latter is really about holding the customer captive. COCE’s coopted version of "Student Success"- purported to be part of an invasive model of academic advising- enables students instead of empowering them. COCE routinely compromises academic standards to ensure that students are "successful" enough to re-enroll in future courses.

pros: Pay is above average, benefits are amazing, time off accrual is better than anywhere.

review_title: Feel like a baby-sitter who is also being baby-sat
pros:
While the adjunct pay isn't great, I've seen lower, and with 8-week terms year round it allows for a steady flow of supplemental income.

As a PhD student, it's been a good way for me to add teaching experience to my C.V.
cons:
Feels like a business model rather than an educational model--at the expense of both instructors and students. Eight-week online undergraduate terms are stacked right on top of each other, often with no days off in between (one term ends on a Sunday and the next begins Monday) and only two days for instructors to submit final grades.  For the students, a regular semester-long course is condensed into eight weeks of learning (often six, with many classes setting aside one week for work on the final project and week 8 for course reflection). This may be fine for academically ambitious students, but that description does not fit most of the students in the course I have taught.

Feels like you are being baby-sat while being asked to baby-sit. Your courses are watched by a team lead, who will email you if your participation in the discussion board is lower than usual one week, if you have even one assignment that has not been graded within 7 days, or if you have not entered a "0" for missing work within 2 days (even though students have an extra week to complete it). In turn, you are expected to email students who are missing work or are not actively participating to "encourage" them or "show support"--but really it feels like you are the first line of defense at making sure students keep passing courses to stay enrolled and therefore pay tuition.

Compromises academic integrity. Each term, I encounter multiple instances of plagiarism issues, ranging from citation/paraphrasing errors to outright full plagiarized assignments. On average, I deal with about half a dozen cases per eight-week term--and my classes are mostly juniors and seniors. Per the direction of the team leads, we're encouraged to use these as a "teaching moment" and allow the students to resubmit the work, without penalty,  and nothing is ever reported. I had one instance that was so egregious, and the student still would not acknowledge what she had done wrong after multiple communications, but when I asked my team lead if I could report it, I was told not to and to still give the student the opportunity to re-do the assignment.

Instructors are course administrators, not teachers. The course content (assignments, discussion prompts, readings, etc.) are pre-set, which is fine, but often are poorly designed, unclear, or out of date. When students evaluate you at the end of the course, your evaluation may be negatively impacted by course features that you are powerless to change. Instructors are told to "customize" the course through the use of announcements, which in my experience a lot of the students do not read. Further, when you do take the time to provide custom instruction above and beyond expectations in these announcements (for example, I post recorded videos interviewing guest speakers), your team lead won't acknowledge this--but will email you if you only post 4 times in the discussion board one week instead of 6 (note that there is no official "rule" of how many times you are required to post, so the distinction between 4 and 6 is completely arbitrary).

job_title: Online Adjunct Professor in Remote, OR
pros: Wow,  I have to write 20 words, I have to write 20 words, I have to write 20 words.
cons:
Wow, I can write SO much more than 20 words!

Okay.  Where to  begin?

First, let's begin with the bachelor's degree itself.  Any student who receives a bachelor's degree has accomplished something - absolutely, and any student who does this deserves to  be commended, it is an achievement to be sure.

HOWEVER, as most academics know, a bachelor's degree in and of itself does not confer automatic career potential as most bachelor's degrees in general are now considered the equivalent of a high school diploma; to REALLY have career advancement potential,  most students will need a graduate degree and therein lies the problem with SNHU and most other schools as well, I might add.

The problem? Insupportable "baby sitting" of students and beyond the pale "hand holding" of students.  Once upon a time, universities were seen as a place of learning and perhaps the single most important skill that CAN NOT be taught but rather, LEARNED, which is: critical thinking and critical analysis skills.

SNHU (and many other schools as well) now expect instructors/professors to almost "shepherd" the student through their course work, almost acting as de facto "parents" being forced to constantly "remind" them of assignments, etc.

Now, having said this, I DO understand that, especially with regards to introductory courses such as the one I am currently (thankfully) finishing for SNHU this might be necessary; however, SNHU's requirements go far beyond this in many ways which I will detail below.

Let's be honest here: SNHU does students a tremendous disservice by all of this ridiculous "hand holding" for this simple reason: not only does it deprive the students of learning  how to think critically and solve problems ON THEIR OWN, but perhaps more importantly, it sets the students up for failure because if/when the student decides to pursue graduate school, the student will then (unfortunately) learn that the "hand holding" that they have been afforded as an undergraduate will NOT be in existence in graduate school, or, if it is, it will be at a vastly reduced capacity because by the time a student enrolls in graduate school it is expected that they have the academic rigor and intellectual capacity that is REQUIRED for graduate level work, full stop.

It's not that graduate professors don't care or won't be available for help, it's just that, they will expect the student to realize that they have assignments and will not spend time "hand holding" and "checking in"; the graduate student will have full responsibility and as a result, will pretty much be left on their  own.

Having said that, here are my thoughts about working as an adjunct for SNHU Online in the COCE (sounds impressive, doesn't it? Hint: it's really not):

A "virtual" tsunami of grading; what does this mean, you might wonder?

The current eight week session is ending and I am beyond thankful and am frankly surprised I have managed to trudge my way through.

I taught an introductory course with 28 students.  The course syllabus has, at minimum, 4 assignments PER WEEK (sometimes 5 assignments if you count the discussion board posts).

Yes, you read that right.

For EACH assignment for EACH student, the instructors are required to leave, at MINIMUM a paragraph of INDIVIDUALIZED feedback.

Yes, you read that right, too.

Now, here is the caveat: if you happen to have a regular full time 40 hour a week job and think "Hey, it would be nice to do a bit of teaching on the side" either for extra money, enjoyment of teaching and imparting knowledge to others, etc., you will realize, only too late, that you have NOT accepted a teaching assignment so much as an invitation to a nightmare in which YOU have unwittingly quite by accident, entered.

When you DO realize this, you will have one of two choices:

To either drop out of the course entirely and realize that as a result, you will then probably never be offered another SNHU course (which in hindsight is probably a good thing) OR to try and do your best.

There is a reason that academic adjunct work is often referred to as "the adjunct ghetto" because it is precisely that: YOU ARE TAKEN ADVANTAGE OF.

I have read, with great interest, the other postings on here; some of them align with my own experience, others do not.  To the postings that talk about "If you're teaching for the money then you shouldn't be in a class room", etc I say with all due respect and politeness: THAT IS A JOKE THAT IS NOT FUNNY.

Anyone who is an academic realizes that, unless they become an administrator, that they will not become wealthy, that is a given.  Most academics start out genuinely loving what they do and genuinely wanting to help and inspire others.

The "tone" of "If you're doing it for the money" is both insulting and disrespectful in several ways: as academics we have worked very hard (and in many cases, accumulated student debt) to do what we do, as instructors/professors we are deserving of a livable wage; notice I said "livable" and NOT "be wealthy" but "livable" as in: we can afford to pay our bills, have benefits (if full time) and perhaps even afford to take a vacation every now and then.

Nothing earth shattering; just a "regular" kind of life.

Here is how SNHU treats it's adjuncts (for those who may be either potential adjuncts and/or students):

For an undergraduate course, instructors are paid $2200 for an 8 week session.

While that may sound like a fair amount, once again here is the caveat: after you deduct for taxes AND when you realize that even though the team leads will tell you (if you ask) that you can expect to spend anywhere from 10-15 hours each week doing class related grading and posting, that is a FALLACY; in addition, as one of the other posters made mention of on here, this then equals out to about roughly $10 (if that, and that is probably a generous estimate) per hour.

Again, remember that the "expectations" for an SNHU adjunct online instructor are that for EACH of the 28 students you MUST provide AT LEAST a paragraph of feedback for EACH of the FOUR/FIVE assignments per WEEK: you can easily then  see how the mythology of "10-15 hours per week" is an outright fabrication and falsehood.

The worst part: after a while, as an instructor, you begin to feel simply overwhelmed with the sheer amount of grading and feedback you are expected to provide; the "team leads" micromanage out the wazoo and you are reprimanded as though you yourself are a student if you deviate from this AT ALL; again, it is both insulting, disrespectful, AND ultimately condescending.

In my current class, out of 28 students, I have a few who seem to be up to the challenge of university course work; most sadly, however, are not and these students and really all SNHU students are being sold a bill of goods: the belief that an SNHU degree will allow them to prosper in the "real world" - some students WILL in fact, prosper, most, however, will not, because as most of us who do have to live in the "real world" know, an individual is held accountable for their ability ultimately, to do, or not do, the job they were hired for.

A sad fact: due to the onslaught of grading (and the arbitrary 'deadlines' for meeting the grading requirements) by the 4th week of my 8 week session, I began to just grade for the sake of grading; it was beyond exhausting and stressful, it was overwhelming.

When I say "grade for the sake of grading" I mean just that: I would often give a cursory glance at the assignment and award the points: I feel guilty for doing this because it is not "who" I am normally, as an instructor; but with the massive amount of grading and feedback required, it was, I sadly discovered, the only way I could even hope to "keep up" with everything required of me.

And this is what saddens me so much: it's a "lose lose" situation both for the students AND for the instructor.  The students deserve so much more than they are receiving; the instructor deserves so much more than they are receiving, too.

No one "wins" - everyone "loses" - yes, the students receive a grade, yes, the instructors receive money (a laughable amount at best); ultimately though, neither student nor instructor truly benefits in any real meaningful way.

Having taken the time to write all of this, I will say: if you are (as I once was) an adjunct struggling to make ends meet by often teaching several courses at often several different universities to cobble together a living wage (been there, done that) then SNHU can serve as a way to do that; but please know this in advance:

You will work an incredible amount for minimal compensation and you will be given students to "work with" who will either need unbelievable amounts of "hand holding" and endless questions that in some cases, can be quite demanding; ie., I had a student this session who constantly emailed with questions and if I did not respond immediately as in, within hours, would then email her academic advisor who would then email me, which of course then led to even MORE work for me.

This is not a self pitying review.  This is an honest review of my experience at SNHU as an online COCE adjunct faculty member.

I have no problem with hard work.  I don't expect to become rich as an academic.

What I DO have a problem with though, as I have discovered, is participating in something that leaves me feeling queasy and not very good about myself as a result; I understand the need for extra money and do not judge anyone for attempting to find ways in which to earn it; however please know this:

If you value your emotional/mental and physical well being, trying to earn extra money as an adjunct for SNHU will take the wind right out of your sails.

There are easier (and less stressful) ways to generate income: even selling items on Ebay would allow this without the hassle of team leads who come across as "hallway monitor" types (I realize the team leads are themselves also adjuncts and I honestly don't know WHY anyone would choose to take on that additional burden but if only for the extra money).

SNHU like many online schools and for that matter, even traditional brick and mortar type universities are all about NUMBERS now; however, these schools go out of their way, through the use of slick advertising and marketing to present otherwise, please don't be fooled by it; it's about the NUMBERS.

pros: All of the staff and my team has been very positive which is wonderful, super helpful and fast acting with questions
cons: The 2.5 late nights that are required. I would much rather work 8-430 everyday. I am much more productive during those hours than late at night

pros: I had my own office, even though it was so tiny that I had to go outside to change my mind
cons: Starvation wages ($2,400 per course, courses capped at 3 per semester); no benefits; was neglected by the assistant Professor who was supposedly supervising me; no opportunity whatsoever for advancement; no opportunities for professional growth; undergraduate students whose writing and research skills were clearly not up to contemporary university academic standards; isolative environment; no job security; a Human Resources Department that was actively hostile to my legitimate concerns.

pros: If you're just starting out and want to get your foot in the door somewhere, this is a good place to do it.  They are hiring like crazy almost constantly (partially because of turnover, but also due to growth).  There are good people here who genuinely care about helping students, and that's a nice thing to be around.
cons:
It's a total rat race, and my department (Student Financial Services) is run by opportunistic weasels who lead with a Game of Thrones mentality.  As a middle manager, I was constantly undermined by my superiors, and spent most of my time navigating the insanely complex and aggravating political environment that has been cultivated over the last 5 years.  To get anything done, it is simply mandatory that you become part of the club, take one for the team at times, and then be strategic about your "ask" for whatever it is that you need.  Yes, it's like that everywhere, but at SNHU you're not going to be dealing with honest brokers most of the time.  It's cutthroat, and you'll get stabbed in the back eventually if you try to be proactive about anything.

From the inside, it's easy to drink the Kool-Aid and think you're part of a movement or something.  Really, you're part of a marketing company.  There's nothing wrong with that, but you're not saving the world either.  The culture, in my department, was toxic at times.  It comes from the top - I regularly sat in meetings with members of the senior leadership who made fun of our students, and our employees.  There is a fundamental lack of respect.

SNHU is ostensibly a nonprofit, but senior leadership is paid at levels that make them among the highest paid in their field.  For a school with a default rate in the double digits, that sends a strange and inappropriate message.

review_title: Cheap Labor-No Loyalty even after 5 years

-The students fail to complete work on time, but expect leniency for late work. They even miss over 50% of the course work, but want you to allow them to make it all up the last week of class. 
-The advisors badger you to give students better grades or let students make up all kinds of work. Some will actually bully you into better grades or incompletes. 
-A LOT of students are not prepared to do college-level work, but they can pass anyways thanks to the default rubric.
-I've given out well-deserved "D's" and "F's"  only be slammed with emails from angry students. The continual passing of low-quality work has set up expectations for other instructors to just hand out "A's" because the student attempted a couple of sentences. Seriously, they can get a good grade because they wrote 2 sentences? 
-24/7 grading, providing more feedback than the student originally posted-see above comment. 
-The expectations are really out of hand and the micromanaging does make you feed devalued.

review_title: Poor Pay, High Pressure, and No Respect for Adjuncts
pros: One can make some money by teaching online.  The school is home to some good students.
cons: Paying $2400 for a 25-student graduate-level class is both insulting and sad.  An instructor makes even less for teaching undergraduates.  There are many intrusive and unqualified administrators who micromanage and bully part-time instructors.  A good portion of the students are in need of remedial instruction in writing and reading comprehension.  There are also burdensome grading requirements.   Students beware: good instructors do not stay here long.

review_title: Middle Management is the Iceberg to SNHU's Ship
job_title: Admissions and Advising in Manchester, NH
pros:
This company has hit gold because they really know how to motivate a person. When I began at SNHU, I loved it. Their CEO has a vision most people can really get behind. Overall the company has drive that has undoubtedly helped millions. Their culture rocks, their benefits are fantastic and they start with four weeks of total PTO (sick included).

In the three years I worked for SNHU, the one thing that made me want to come to work every day was the people. Not only my teammates, but my students as well. It was an incredible mix of passionate people truly trying to make a difference and help their students persist. I made incredible connections, and the experience I gained here will help me be a better version of myself for years to come.

The TL;DR is that the people you work next to every day could end up being some of the most wonderful connections you have ever made. I looked forward to coming in every day because of the people that I wanted to see! They recognize the importance of social ties, and we are allowed the freedom to chat and do our own thing for a little as long as we are getting everything done and have the time.
cons:
Now I want to make a very clear distinction, when I say the people here are the best part- that excludes the mass majority of management. Most of them really suck, because they only care about you as long as you're making them look good.

Whether it's admissions, advising, or finance- the office politics will throttle any true passions you have. If you're not ready to play the Game, consider yourself already done for and in for a frustrating 4 or more years stuck in a single department with no room for growth. If you want to move up, 4/5 odds you will experience a pay cut, political backstabbing or witch hunting. You will become fearful of the plethora of metrics not because you know it will help assert you're doing your job well, but because you wonder what small slip may be twisted against you. Gossip abounds in every crevice, every department, every skype business group chat.

9/10 your manager or director cares way more about the numbers and their advancement than they do with you.
