pros: Coworkers. That is it.
cons: Everything about this place is a sham. The middle management, team leads and directors are absolutely worthless. The rampant nepotism creates a structure of incompetence. They force registrations even if the students dont want them. Then, the student non-pars out resulting in an R2T4. They do this to doctor their numbers to make it look like they are doing better than they actually are. This place should be shut down for fraud. I feel bad for the students on campus who pay $200k to get the same degree as the students online who pay like $30k. All of management have their degrees from other shotty universities like University of Phoenix and Kaplan. Everything about this university is FOR PROFIT, dont let them fool you. Don't fall into this toxic trap.

pros: Fantastic benefits. That's about it.
cons:
First, I keep seeing reviews that say, "how can anyone complain?" The complaints are valid, and acting like employees need to suck it up and deal with it won't address the real issues people have here. Those types of reviews reek of incentives. 

Second, over my time here, the culture has changed. We have moved from having a focus on knowing the students and helping them succeed to filling seats, no matter if they are ready for college or not. We are not a for-profit, we shouldn't act like one. If school is not in the student's best interest, if they are not ready, then pushing them to start as hard as the directors want is going to lead to a lot of term one drops. We have a reputation for accepting anyone, and I had spoken to several potential students who were put off by that. This goal of getting as many students into classes as possible is incredibly short sighted and will lead to a lot of negative views for the school in the long term.

Before I left, there was a survey tool that was sent out to employees to get feedback on how they felt things were going and gather any suggestions on what to fix. This was eventually shut down, and if memory serves the reason was "security issues." Despite them telling us that it was no longer available, team leads still had access to it. This tells me that they heard our complaints, and instead of looking to fix the issues they decided enough was enough and it would be better to turn off the anonymous surveys to ignore us.

Some team leads have no business in a leadership role. There is a difference between a boss and a manager. If your body starts violently shaking when an employee asks you for clarification and doesn't take "because I said so" as a respectable answer, you probably fall into the "boss" camp. We work at a university, I expect my supervisors to be able to give better explanations. And if you don't know the answer to something, just say that! Say that you don't know, then use the resources that are available to you as a supervisor to find some answers.

I've known a few employees who disclosed that they had mental difficulties with their position and wanted to transfer to a different department, however they were denied due to not being there long enough. They were then promptly terminated. This brings in two issues: the lack of support for those who suffer mental difficulties made worse by these positions, and the inability to transfer to a different position that would be more suited towards a person's strengths. The employee handbook tells us that an employee would need to be with SNHU for 9 months before switching departments, however if you were hired through a temp agency this would change to 12 months. So far, I have yet to get an acceptable answer on why this policy exists. If one person worked at SNHU for, say, 8 months in the admission department, and wanted to switch to enrollment and support services, they would be denied over someone who comes in with no knowledge of how SNHU operates. Someone fresh off the street would have a better chance of getting a position than someone who already works there.

review_title: Evolving higher ed while traditional higher ed tries to keep its historical hierarchy
pros:
The curriculum is evolving constantly to build a human instructors presence into competency-based models of learning.  Its a big place that still tries to connect with its adjuncts, especially in the Business School. The standards are improving for minimal contributions by instructors.

 If anyone says its a glorified grading job, they wont be employed here long. The whole competitive advantage of the institution originates for a few simple tenants. 1) expect that adult learners must prioritize family and work before education but that is no less critical in their lives, 2) Coach, dont pontificate - its not your job anymore- guiding learners at their own pace and finding the correct motivations to have them reach to be something greater is part of your job, 3) there is plenty of academic freedom to add to the course content -but you have to actually take the time to do it - most dont, 4) No one has EVER told me to pass a student when I didnt feel they were ready.  I've been backed up every time, 5) Understand that almost half of these students have tried college before at the undergrad level and not finished. They are at risk before they even start. 

Something has to be different about SNHU to serve this population of adult learners and its not going to be the textbooks or website.  Its the integration of competency learning and human support via faculty/peers/advisors and the level of effort they are willing to put in as mentors demonstratingrigorous academic and professional behaviors and capabilities.
cons: Constant evolution means less stability if you need that. Online learning entails superior instructors to spend 12-15 hours working with students, the content, and grading.  If you don't have the passion or the time, dont apply. Yes, pay could be a touch higher, but its not bad.

review_title: For your Mental Health...pass on this
job_title: Student Finance Counselor in Manchester, NH
pros:
Benefits, you will have great time off and medical benefits. 
If you drink the SNHU kool aid you will be fine.
cons:
-If you speak your mind at all or criticize management in any way you will be labeled negative. 
-They will hold you to nearly impossible metrics and tell you everyone is meeting them except you. They are also not happy when you ask around to other people if anyone else is struggling because i can promise other people are struggling just as much as you. They lie to you. 
-If you want to work here, prepare to be nit picked apart, and monitored on calls but they will call it feedback and ask you "don't you want to be the best you can be" "how will you improve if you have nothing to work on" when in reality you're doing a great job.
-The team leads are not professional. They often go out drinking with their staff and I have heard rumors of them having inappropriate relations with coworkers. They will also put you down as often as they can and remind you they are in charge. They will belittle you and if you try to go to upper management they will cry and get you in trouble for attacking them. However, if confronted the TLs  will tell you are providing positive feedback and you are interpreting it wrong. 
- you will be verbally abused daily by students who have no business in college. Don't go to management they will ask what you could have done to handle the student better, even though it's the students fault. 
-you will be micromanaged, everything you do throughout the day will be watched. 
- they will promise in 9 months you can changed rolls but there are 30 people going for the same role. They refer to SFS as the feeder dept. because it feeds other depts. Most people change positions or leave.

review_title: Not as strong as they once were
pros: Benefits at a reasonable cost to employees,  vacation time, discounted food at all office locations, relaxed atmosphere and dress code
cons: A lot of management changes has lead to some confusion in direction and instability.  Large amount of outsourcing to India. People directly involved with the work are not consulted as to best practices- managers removed from the work make decisions that don't always make sense, then are reversed when they fail.

review_title: Unhappy Adjunct for Graduate Classes, too
job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Because I have to fill 20 words, I will say that a positive is that they hired me to teach.
cons: First and last time teaching for SNHU as an adjunct—the workload they expect is absolutely insane and unreasonable for an online class that pays $2500 (a graduate level class).  It's almost full-time work in terms of communication, grading, and other requirements. Most students are completely unprepared for the level of coursework, which isn't even up to par with other comparable graduate courses. This degree won't do anything for students and I honestly feel teaching for this school is unethical for both myself and for students.

review_title: COCE Upper Academics Management - Lack of Experience- Self Centered
pros: I love the mission and culture,  and the EVP is certainly focused on innovation,  collaboration and student success.
cons: Academics management presents themselves as very self-centered so unless you are willing to step on someone's back or stab them in the back, you will not advance in your position.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: The rigor and organization of the courses for the online Environmental Studies surpasses other universities.  My experience with the faculty and administrators has been very positive and supportive.  The caliber of students within the program are dedicated and above average in their studies.  This bodes well not only for the success of the students, but also for the online degree program.
cons: I wish there was an opportunity to advance levels and pay grade in the online environment.

pros: The work environment is positive,we work as individuals with our students but also as teams to make the best decisions for the students. Our students have support from the admissions process, through financial aid to advising and education. As a student as well as an employee I am receiving my master's degree and I am working with well educated faculty who are available to me. There is additional assistance for students as well. I have never worked for a company that after your 90 day probationary period you have 4 weeks personal time.You are encouraged to take a week off each quarter and if you are not able you can roll over one week or get paid for it. There are time restrictions around the start  dates but there are many other time frames to have time approved. I have never felt more welcomed and comfortable in a company than here at SNHU. There are many scheduled Town Hall meetings as well as Round Table meetings where our top management address the entire staff, These meetings are honestly delivered and we are always aware of the state of the school. Yes there are changes and challenges that's what keeps us the best. In the terrible winter storms we have the opportunity to work from home, there are Employee Appreciation Days. I have a great respect  for this company and look forward to this being my last journey towards a rewarding retirement when I get old enough to do that. There are opportunities to grow and develop here as well. I feel as though I can go on for days I am so happy and excited to come to work every day. To be able to love what you do is the greatest gift in life and I love working for Southern New Hampshire University.
cons:
Not one I can think of. Yes we do park off sight but we do not pay for that parking the school does also they supply us with shuttle transportation. I have worked at many companies where you parked off site, as a seasoned worker I build this fact into my commute.
I suppose if you are not used to working in the world of expectations the pace could be overwhelming,you are expected to be  on time and do your job.

job_title: Team Lead and Instructor in Chicago, IL
pros:
Asynchronous learning means I can check into my classes whenever I am hanging out online. I check in daily for about 10 minutes, then set aside a few hours three days a week for grading, forum management, and announcement writing.
They offer benefits like raises after 15 terms, ability to take classes for free, and even a fund for presenting at conferences
They offer terms year-round so you have a steady income to supplement your main job. An extra $1000 a month helps enormously.
The first time you teach a course, it takes more time, but I average 8 hours a week. They start at $2200/8 week term and give raises too so it's a good wage in the end.
Really, this is just a casual side job. 80% of the students just do the work. 10% drop off the radar or have a crisis. Another 10% are really chatty and ask you a lot of questions via email. If you view this job like checking an academic facebook, you'll see why the money is pretty fantastic.
The school is really into supporting its students, but it is NOT "get them through at all costs." In my 7 years here, I have always been supported over any student issue, and if I'm not comfortable giving that student the benefit of the doubt, I have never been forced to change my grades. I can't say that about all my schools.
cons:
The team lead program can be a dream or a nightmare -- either you have someone reliable to ask questions about pushy students, or you have a micro-manager. Once you are a good instructor, though, you only have an annual review so that's not too much pressure.
Some classes put the final project due in week eight, and those classes require a ton of grading in a 48 hour period. Redesigned courses have the final draft due in Module 7 so you have the full week.
The best class is 20 students. Standard is 25, but popularity means that some classes have 28 students. That can be tough if no one drops out the first week. Classes don't have 30. That's an exaggeration.

pros: Without a doubt the best place I've worked in the past twenty years.  CfA is mission driven (giving folks who never had a shot at an education a chance to obtain one).  Mgmt puts the students first and treats the employees like family.  Smart, hard working, and creative employees.  True family, work/life balance with flexible Fridays and reasonable office hours.   The most innovative competency based education provider in the education space.
cons: They have to figure out how to break the nut on explosive growth.

pros:
-Benefits (medical)
-Vacation (although you will not be able to use it)
cons:
SNHU takes the majority of their income in the form of financial aid from the federal government (taxpayers). 

They then riddle adult learners with debt and do not even graduate 50% of 90k+ online students...in 8 years. Student loan debt will cripple entire generations and SNHU is a major culprit. 

It was really sad seeing thousands of "students" taken advantage of by false hopes of prosperity from a Bachelor's degree. Sickening.

SNHU is the most negative representation of higher education being a consumer good. Seeing people by the thousands be taken advantage while aiding the process through my employment was the biggest professional mistake of my life.

pros: COCE - the online arm of SNHU, is an amazing place to work.  The leadership team has cultivated an environment where student learning is valued, innovation is encouraged, and there is alignment between mission and action.
cons: Working at SNHU requires you to show up, each day, eager to change the world.  This isn't a place to hide, doing minimal work, while you wait for retirement to kick in.

pros: I truly enjoy teaching for SNHU. The student and faculty support, the structure and organization of the courses, faculty development, and the interaction with on-line faculty and team leads, all contribute to SNHU being a fabulous place to teach. Although I teach on-line as an adjunct I feel a strong connection to the students, faculty, and administration because of the structure SNHU has created and maintains.
cons: I have no complaints or "cons."

job_title: Online Adjunct Professor in Manchester, NH
pros:
Non-profit school should be good opportunity for new instructors looking to get experience.
Work from home
cons:
Workload has increased beyond belief. They require an obscene amount of feedback to students who are not accountable to read it. 
Team lead is required to micromanage instructors.
There are no admissions standards so many students are incapable of writing a college-level paper. 
There is no penalty to students for academic integrity violations. If they plagiarize they are simply allowed to redo the work.
Hire too many instructors and therefore wont have enough classes for seasoned faculty.

pros: The other employees, the general culture, the work I did was rewarding.
cons: I didn't feel I could set boundaries between when I was "on the clock" and when I was home. Highly political environment. Pay is not great, but expected from a nonprofit. Benefits are great.

pros: Now I know how my students feel when they are trying to meet word count and have nothing to say about a topic.
cons:
- $2500 for a 10 week class of 30 students. If you work 7 days a week (it's encouraged and you kinda have to if you want to comply with  the 'replies to student email' policy), that is roughly 36 dollars per day. 
- Most weeks you are grading 90 assignments. Each assignment needs to have detailed feedback (that most students don't read, or read and ignore). I timed how long it took me to do that if I did my job right - aka read each assignment and then provide the feedback the student needed and also deserved. Grading alone took 30 hours. 
- You have to reply to every discussion board post no matter how pathetic of a post it is. 30 posts are the norm and you have to seriously think about what to say for about 20 of those totals you at least 5 hours. 
- Total time = 35 hours per week at 7 dollars an hour (using $250/week). That is no longer a part-time job. I'd like a salary and benefits now please. Oh, I can't have those? Then let me do the sane thing: Skim student work, copy/paste canned response, don't hand out anything less than a B- or else there are endless student emails in your future and done!
- Sounds like this approach to grading is similar to that we read about in the papers for the maligned for-profit 'colleges' that shove students through and graduate people who can't read, write, and function like we expect college graduates to function? Well, it is! SNHU is a for-profit diploma mill hiding behind the not-for-profit sanctimonious marketing SNHU puts out. 
- Not scaring you yet? How about submitting 8 cases for plagiarism and getting all 8 denied. All 8 cases had about 50-80% of the content totally copied and pasted from the internet, sometimes from Wikipedia. Reason given: well, the student cited their sources, they are just confused about paraphrasing. Are they now? Or are these MBA students just hip to the fact that they can get away with academic murder as long as it is APA conform?
- Not triggering your deep sense of right and wrong yet? How about watching a student who has no business being in a high school, let alone the MBA program get their tuition credited towards retaking the class under another professor because you failed the student for submitting incomprehensible drivel. Checked her LinkedIn profile later that year and yep, she graduated with an MBA from SNHU. Hmmm.
- The micromanaging Leads will then ring the death knell for your SNHU funeral. Every comma in your gradebook is evaluated, every email sent criticized. I'm predicting that the first AI application for a non-military purpose will be online adjunct professors being replaced by an AI. It won't even have to be a particularly advanced or smart AI.

pros:
- Team Members are great.  If this was solely rating my coworkers on my team, it would be a five star review for them, including my manager.  I tended to stick within my team, so I can't speak for anywhere else at the university.

- Job is satisfying in that you get a few students that are great to work with and work very hard to achieve their goals.

- Benefits are good if you are married and have kids (health plan is pretty decent).

- Job is easy.

- My immediate manager was very accommodating.  If I had a doctor's appointment, was a few minutes late due to the shuttles or needed to put in PTO on short notice, she was very understanding.  Also allowed us to do our jobs without micromanagement.
cons:
- Pay is very low.  Advisors are required to have a college degree and start at $35,000, which is low for Manchester area.  Comparable entry level jobs that require a college degree generally start at $42,000 - $48,000 in that area.

- Promotion is a convoluted, time consuming and overly centralized process.  You need to attend a bunch of seminars, write some pretty pointless essays about them and brand behaviors and sit on an interview panel composed of people that have nothing to do with your management chain.  All this to get promoted to Level II or III, where you do essentially the exact same job as at Level I.

- There is nothing here to differentiate between good work and bad work.  If you are giving 110% every day, there is nothing that differentiates you from someone giving 10% every single day.  No accelerated promotion.  No enhanced promotion opportunities.  No incentive pay or yearly bonus.  Nothing.

- Very odd set-up where there are for-profit metrics but the university keeps pitching its nonprofit status.  We keep hearing about how much revenue the university is generating, but anyone who understands accounting/finances know that revenues are a small part of the picture and taking revenue increases as proof of growth is a foolish idea.  Similarly, we have basically sales metrics, but no one is bonused or measured against them, so why do they exist for employees (I can see management using them to track progress).

- Ultimately, low salary, no incentive pay, a convoluted and strictly timed promotion process can make this feel like a dead end job.  

- Open enrollment is horrible.  You get students that can't write a coherent sentence or do basic mathematics.  Education should be affordable for everyone, but I've literally seen students that write worse college papers than what I wrote in 7th grade.  There needs to be some sort of standard.

pros:
Work from home

No need to leave your home
cons:
They pay external faculty half of what they pay internal faculty to do the same amount of work.

Highly micromanaged

Grading expectations are burdensome and prevent faculty from behind able to have the time to actually engage with their students and course.

pros: Flexible work schedule is all I can think of.
cons: Micromanagement, use of rubrics to grade which allow about 97% to earn a passing grade, lots of grading and feedback required = pay of about $10. an hour, if lucky.  Students seem to think the instructors set up the courses - which is sad, but of course most shouldn't be enrolled to begin with. I would never hire a student with an online degree.

review_title: SNHU is a great place to work
pros:
-amazing support from teammates and supervisors
-fantastic benefits 
-feeling like you are making a difference to your students
-ability to earn remote days is terrific
-flex time for working the weekend shifts is awesome
cons: -two nights working until 9:00 at night is tough

pros: There are a lot of pro's to this University. Many are named by others  but I will restate them anyway. The benefits package is amazing. Medical and dental are 10x better than anywhere I have ever worked. The atmosphere and culture are fantastic as well. There is a really laid back atmosphere. They offer volunteer paid time off, along with a great amount of PTO. Incredible opportunities for personal and professional development that can take you all over the country.  I love the people I work with. Meetings are generally more than reasonable. There is an incredible amount of communication and transparency from management. I feel that many of the negative aspects pointed out are personal problems or failure to pay attention. Especially seeing SNHU as a non-profit. SNHU has programs running all over the country and world. We partner with many different organizations, hold job fairs, work with local, national and international charities and non-profits.  Our military programs are above and beyond. We help with the Run to Home Base, The Tough Ruck and the Celtics scoring in Transition  to name a few. Every organization is going to have disgruntled employees who will do anything to try to hurt the organization they are not pleased with, so many of these reviews are to be expected. Hearing adjunct faculty say that students aren't learning anything should show the quality of said adjunct faculty. It is really disheartening to here people say they have "too much work" as it is definitely fair and balanced (although I do believe SFS is getting bat down pretty hard). There are times, like the week before and after term start where things can get pretty hectic, but it is not a stressful job.  Our advising directors,  training team and President are absolutely incredible people!  On campus facilities, pool, gym, fields, labs.
cons:
It is an open enrollment school as far as COCE goes which I believe in a lot of cases brings a negative view of SNHU. Students can be unbelievably abusive to faculty, staff with no repercussions.  Adjunct faculty is not consistent. Many instructors are just looking for a paycheck for doing little to no work, miss deadlines, don't give adequate feedback, do not have open lines of communication with students, can have belittling  attitudes to other students, have problems working with military students and can be testy with advisor's and staff. Other instructors are absolutely out of this world fantastic, so the consistency in hiring is random at best.  Pay could definitely be better, but the benefits more than make up for it. It does seem that SNHU is on the lower end of the pay scale. 

The turnover rate is quite high all around which can be very negative for student success. Too much moving around. Every few months it seems you are having to over your office or pod to a different area, sometimes all over the building. Consistently changing programs can be hard to keep up with.  Parking is hell.

review_title: Great place to work and amazing people
pros:
It is an environment where you are given the freedom to drive results.
Not micromanaged - allowed to be a business owner for your own work.
Able to take on more and do more.  The benefits are so much better than the business world. The cost of insurance  lower with better coverage which equals more money in money in my families pocket. 
Amazing supervisors and colleagues!
Best place to work!
cons: I can't think of one. Leaving the business world and going into higher education was the best decision I could have made!

pros: They send pay on time
cons: Micromanagement.  They try to tell PhD's how to teach.   If one student is unhappy with a score, even if it is one point out of a thousand points available and the student clearly deserved the mark down, management requires instructors to make the student happy no matter what.   In other words, the student is always right and the instructor is always wrong.

review_title: SNHU is a Great Place to Work
pros:
1)  Intense training...from day one is was clear that we were to take every aspect of our jobs seriously.  

2)  It was clear that our priority, our focus, our reason for being, is the success of the students.  

3)  Inclusiveness...you name a flavor of human being, and they are reflected here.  Maybe not in abundance, but then this is New England...not New Mexico, Not Georgia, not Alaska...which is even more impressive that the diversity is as broad as it is....ages, ethnicities, beliefs, etc.

4)  Ongoing training...SNHU puts its money where its mouth is.  

5)  Equipped to do our jobs...we are given the best equipment to use to get our jobs done, and a super, fantastic IT department to help us at a moment's notice if something isn't working correctly.  

7)  Benefits...they are world-class!  Excellent medical, dental, etc.  And of course the tuition coverage is heaven sent.

8)  Location...easy on and off the highway.  Traffic does slow down at peaks periods...but that shouldn't be a surprise.  Also parking garage is right next door.

9)  In-house amenities...fully equipped gym.  Kitchens on each floor.  Great cafe.  And the cafe food is discounted to employees!  

10)  Flexible work hours...I hear repeatedly that employees are able to work out schedules that meet their needs.  The ability to work remotely a couple of days a weeks is also a huge benefit.

11)  Excellent quarterly meetings...lots of good information to help us see the impact of what we're doing.  

12)  Lots of opportunities to share our thoughts...and evidence that we're heard.

13)  Fun atmosphere....lots of celebrations and activities.
cons:
1)  Multitasking is king.  You need to be okay with multi-tasking constantly.

2)  Loud from a lot of voices, and hard surfaces.

3)   Training is intense, with a lot to learn in a relatively short time.

4) Institutional information database is not intuitive.

pros: Culture culture culture. This is a values-driven non-profit and everything they do is in the best interest of the student. Everyone is very positive and supportive. They have excellent benefits and 25 paid days off per year. They gave us a $300 stipend when we started working from home to set up our home office.
cons: The work is tedious and can be boring. Not very intellectually stimulating.

pros: People value each-other at SNHU and there is a benefits package to rival all others. It is an overall pleasant place to work and a great community particularly for those 35 and younger. Lots of young people.
cons: Pay is not regionally competitive with positions similar to those within a fifty mile radius, management often hires externally often leaving little growth for internal employees.

review_title: Not the Place for Those with Integrity
pros:
- Work is consistent and constant
- Always developing and changing
- Fellow reviewers/instructors are friendly and care about their students
cons:
- Seem perfectly okay with cheating students
- Threaten your job if you say anything about anyone cheating
- Goal leads and some higher ups throw their weight around even when they're wrong
- Students are not held accountable for poor attitudes, cheating, and plagiarizing

job_title: Marketing Director/Vice President in Manchester, NH
pros: Constantly changing work and stimulating challenges.  Leadership that truly believes in its non profit mission, and that is both humble and visionary.  Unbeatable resources for a non profit.   Fantastic benefits.
cons: Incredible growth over past years results in quirks and gaps in some process and other areas.  Some depts are fast, others are more of a traditional/slower academic speed.

job_title: Online Adjunct Professor in Manchester, NH
pros: Good pay, $2200/course for 8 weeks and have all of the support that is needed.
cons: I sometimes feel like I have a babysitter who is constantly nagging me about things that must be done by the weeks end. We are adults, treat us like adults. There is no need to have babysitters.

review_title: Doing the right thing by the student
pros: I imagine it is difficult to find another place to work where your management and colleagues TRULY want you to do the right thing for your students.  I appreciate the clarity of the vision and the transparency of the organization with what we are working on and where we're headed.  I am supported in my own professional growth and I believe management values my happiness.
cons: Working in an old mill building has its challenges.  Parking is tough in a semi-urban setting.

pros: Culture is catered towards millennial generation which could be good or bad depending on your age. Great benefit package and lots of time off. Lots of upward mobility if you are motivated.
cons: Basically operates as a call center. You have a caseload of students you work with, but many of them do not answer your calls. You spend the majority of your day answering calls that come through the main line or helping your students who are performing poorly.

pros: I've been teaching at SNHU for approximately 3 years and I can truly say it's been one of the best teaching experiences that I've had over the last 12 years.   The university appears to do a much better job of screening applicants and supporting its accepted students which makes instruction and the overall learning environment so much more enjoyable.
cons: I have not been able to identify any negatives over the last 3 years

job_title: Military Admission Counselor in Manchester, NH
pros: you have a wonder group of people to work with along with the students that are usually appreciative of your effort. You make decent money with Great
cons: You will have to deal with workforce politics unfortunately, and if you are passionate about what you do you will have a LOT of work  thrown at you because not everyone is and will slack.

pros: COCE SNHU does an excellent job at feeding and obsessing over the culture --but isn't taken well by all.  Operates on the notion that everything is awesome and everything is cool, similar to the Lego movie.
cons: Team Leads aren't equipped with skills or have no prior management experience.  Too driven by t pushing productivity and no room for collaboration and new ideas within teams.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Traverse City, MI
pros: Remote, helping students to succeed
cons: Create classes for no extra pay, if you complain you are told you will not get class next time, low pay, told  not to fill out forms for other courses as you  are teaching already but yet they are advertising for adjuncts all the time. Called various depth no help, basically, on my own.

job_title: Online Adjunct Professor in Atlanta, GA
pros: The university works very hard to keep improving.  The teachers are held to very strict standards in order to benefit the students. We facilitators each have mentors/advisors who grade our performance and provide opportunities for growth as professionals.
cons: We are only allowed to teach one class at a time.

review_title: Love working for SNHU as an adjunct instructor!
job_title: Adjunct Instructor/Subject Matter Expert in Alexandria, VA
pros: Decent adjunct contract fees (compared to many other adjunct teaching gigs at other institutions); student advisers work as a team with adjuncts to ensure student success; decent leadership in IT undergrad program (meaning good support from above).
cons: Most adjunct instructional positions are online only (not necessarily a con, just be aware of what you're getting into); a WIDE variety of commitment level among online students makes personal engagement a challenge.

pros: They use D2L for their LMS.
cons:
They have "monitors" in the course watching what you do. If you give a student extra time to complete an assignment, that is not allowed. You have to have a phone meeting and get admonished. Every Wednesday, you have to submit "zeros" for students who did not hand in their assignments. It's holy hell if you don't submit the zeros. Again, you get a phone call and get admonished. 

Money isn't good, either. $2400 a course with an average of 27-28 students.

review_title: Joining SNHU was the best thing I have done!
job_title: Student Finance Counselor in Manchester, NH
pros: Starting a job at Southern New Hampshire University was the best thing I could have done for myself! The support staff here is absolutely amazing.  Management makes their staff feel appreciated and  supported.   The benefits that are offered are great! There are so many opportunities for growth within the company.   I can not say enough good things about how SNHU treats their employees!
cons: My one con would be that the hours are  not the best.

pros: I feel very fortunate to work with a talented group of professionals in an innovative environment with a common mission to provide the best support for our students. Our core values are consistently reinforced in our day-to-day work at all levels.
cons: I haven't encountered any negatives.

pros: The benefits are just about it. Medical, dental, eye, tuition and PTO time off are amazing. I can’t imagine that without these anyone would stay here (or at least in the millyard working for COCE). Beyond that I dread every day that I have to wake up and return here.
cons: My god where do I begin. The entire online portion of the university is run like a high stress, micro managed call center. While it is true that admissions and student finance have it the worst, even advising is treated like a call center. We are reviewed weekly on our “quality” and while being told that we can do what is best for the student, every single interaction is picked apart and graded like a middle schooler in a class room. The school accepts anyone with a loan or pay check regardless if they are illiterate or completely unprepared. The workload/expectations are down right unmanageable for the measly $35K you make in advising. The students will verbally abuse you over the phone and you are held responsible for their own success or failure rate. I’ve never seen a more pathetic excuse of a university. Truly it’s a corporate business hiding under the image of “not for profit” which is actually different than a non profit. I’ve never been more unhappy, stressed and mentally exhausted in my whole life. stay away at all costs. PS SNHU wants to be a monopoly in New England over higher ed. They rag on university of Phoenix but we are the exact same.

review_title: Terrible! They treat Adjuncts horribly - Diploma Mill
job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros: Work from home for asynchronous class
cons: If you are an Adjunct, you will work long hours for less than minimum wage. They have changed. After 3 years it is insane the amount of work they expect for NO MONEY. They assign crazed Team Leads who micromanage every single thing you do. If you don't enter 0s on Wednesday, you will be emailed and it will be a big deal. Now you have to do it by Monday and beg students to hand in assignments with their "easy campaign" it's humiliating! The grading is a JOKE. Professors are pressured to give out easy grades. D work is A-. F work is B-. Students can not do anything all term and then randomly catch up. Every term you get a different Team Lead who will fail your evaluation for things like not bolding an announcement! They treat Adjuncts lower than a janitor, you are little more than a data entry clerk. They have zero respect for expertise and knowledge. They have created really stupid and meaningless Rubrics that require you to fill in endless boxes. Students don't even read the boxes. Quality feedback doesn't matter you just have to fill in the boxes!!!! Classes that used to have an attendance cap they removed the cap and kept the workload and doubled the students. It's insanity. Team Leads are there to micromanage and fail you. There is no upside. Who would want to work in this environment? Some of the students are great others are barely literate. There is zero respect, zero morale. There is no consistency on assignments, no benefits. I saw a chart and it's an extremely high turnover job. They don't care!!!! They have set up a system where they exploit Adjuncts and rip off students in the name of "education." It has become a diploma mill. They don't care. They don't pay a living wage. Students post one sentence on the Discussion Board and you are required to reply within 24 hours THEN you are required to write detailed feedback and fill out all the boxes in the Rubric or you are admonished in email by a Team Lead and failed! All this on one sentence!!! Someone over at SNHU has gone haywire with these stupid alogrithms and parsing out everything, they've become so bureaucratic it's like 1984 and the human element is removed. Algorithm this: YOU SUCK AND YOU WILL NEVER REPLACE REAL COLLEGE. Often times you are duplicating work. The Modules are designed such that there is a LOT of busywork. Some Modules are so poorly designed students are confused and the emails start flooding your inbox and you must reply! Some students are crazy and will never stop emailing. Some Modules have wrong terminology and typos and it never gets corrected. The Team Leads are part of the Dark Side and are not with the Force. They know they are Darth Vader but they do it because they get an extra $300 a term. Pathetic. Treat people better or the institution will pay the price. Start with giving Adjunct academic professors respect and allowing them freedom to actually provide REAL GRADES. Just stop with the insanity and stop basing your entire educational business model on EXPLOITATION.

job_title: Senior Project Manager in Manchester, NH
pros: Team environment, communication, benefits, leadership, development
cons: Parking, pace, three more words

job_title: Graduate Academic Advisor in Manchester, NH
pros: There are some really nice people that work there. My peers were the best!
cons:
SNHU is the McDonalds of higher ed. It’s cheap, quick, and low quality. The courses are cranked out and the assignments put online for students to do and get into their instructor, who didn’t actually create any of the content but then has to grade it. I amazed this place is still accredited. 
I worked in graduate advising for two years from 6/2016-6/2018. While there are some great people who work there, the team leads are so far up each other’s’ rear ends that they have lost sight of what it is like to be an advisor.
The whole institution is so caught up on the numbers that it wasn’t a “people” job anymore. It was all about how many calls you can make in a week and how many students you could get registered. You are encouraged to convince students to register even if they don’t really want to or tell you they can’t handle the course load, making it more of a sales position than actually helping anyone out. Towards the end of the term you have to call student who aren’t registered once a week.  They try and make it better by buying everyone ice cream a couple times a year.
They need metrics on EVERYTHING. You are given a list of exactly what students you need to call for the week and what to say to them. The following week you team lead gives you a grade on whether or not you did it. Stay away and work for a real college. They might as well have auto-dialers and recorded messages. In short, don’t work here. Don’t go here. It’s a McChicken with cheese.

pros: Great support from team leads, deans, library professionals. Fair pay. Most students are truly engaged.
cons: Some weeks are very busy with heavy grading loads. You will want to check in to email (at least) seven days a week. You'll probably work weekends to meet grading deadlines, but this improves as you gain experience.

pros: Honestly the only pro is that they run a lot of classes so you can get consistent teaching work if you want it.
cons: The pay is low compared to other schools, compounded by the large class sizes makes the pay comparatively even worse.

review_title: Adjuncts are treated better than most places
pros: Adjuncts are treated well and loyalty is rewarded with benefits. Tuition waiver, conference grants, regular pay raises and due process with HR if you're performing suboptimally, which adds job security.
cons: Adjuncts are micro managed a lot and don't have much creative freedom. Grading workload is high for pay.

review_title: Innovative and fast paced environment, in an organization with visionary leadership and a great mission.
pros: If you want to work hard... for a great mission... and develop professionally... SNHU could be a great fit for you.
cons: May not match people’s expectations about what the culture and pace of a higher education institution is / should be. SNHU culture mirrors more of what might expected at commercial companies.

review_title: Great people, great place to work
job_title: Associate Director, Creative Management in Manchester, NH
pros: SNHU treats employees with respect, dignity and an unusual level of care. The management team has built an incredible culture. I  worked there for five years and look back with nothing but appreciation for all of it.
cons: It's a big place, so it can take a while to get your voice heard if you're not an extrovert. But the culture allows for diverse perspectives and most managers do a great job of advocating for the individuals on their teams.

review_title: SNHU - A Great Place to Work!
job_title: Adjunct Online Professor & Team Lead in Pensacola, FL
pros: The best reasons to work at SNHU - THE ADMINISTRATION, THE FACULTY and THE STUDENTS!  In addition, the compassionate and caring attitudes of those I work with are the best I've ever been associated with!
cons: The "Cons" for SNHU are little to non-existent!

pros: Pay is great and the increase as you teach more classes.
cons: VERY closely monitored by Team Leads. Most of the assignments are written assignments. None of the assessments are proctored. You are expected to comment on every Discussion post.

pros: Well, they hired some contractors who actually know about business to come in and try to make this crazy operation scalable. There are rooms for nursing mothers to pump,  stunning ($$$) marketing, and you might think this university is run by competent people. Alas, when contractors leave, so does any semblance of a progressive, well-run organization.
cons:
SNHU has exploded in growth very quickly. (I'm guessing it's a bubble and we will see a lot of vacant buildings and unemployment when it pops.)  

Management is staffed by right-place-right-time promotions. Staff with no executive experience anywhere, literally former chain-restaurant waitresses, are making executive decisions on hundreds to thousands of staff. The woman who runs the whole online school is one of such promotions. She's impressed with her quick rise to executive level and loves to hear herself talk and all employees are required to attend webinars in which she repeatedly begins sentences with the phrase, "I got where I am because..." When asked her favorite book on management, she replied, "Wicked." (Yes, the book version of a broadway show. But, like, they are in a school and like, they're friends, so obvious connection to snhu.)  When faced with making real management decisions, management grasps at straws and makes legally questionable decisions. They have a whole slew of exempt employees (the academic advisors) that they treat as exempt employees, tacitly condoning unpaid overtime. Yet they then make ludicrous night and weekend scheduling requirements (don't worry--they'll show you the charts to justify why that smart Middle-schooler could poke holes in). 

They encourage a high turnover rate and are actually not invested in retention whatsoever. If you can't work nights they will ask you to quit. (Hint: you don't actually have to and if you need the paycheck you have every legal protection to keep going in in normal business hours.) They don't give yearly raises commensurate with inflation, period. The only way to earn more money is to be promoted. They pay borderline poverty wages--advisors come in at $28-38k ish.  The housing market in that area is growing at 7-10% per year and SNHU employees don't even get a 3-5% bump on their pay check. 

My advice to current staff is don't make any major life decisions (purchasing a house, etc.) on SNHU alone because it's just unlikely to be sustainable between the lack of retention and the strong likelihood that it's a bubble.

The "education" they purport to provide. Ohhhh boy. The concepts are elementary at best. The texts are literal picture books, rife with spelling and grammatical errors.  And the best part, all of those former chain restaurant waitresses and uneducated management with no experience pursue SNHU online courses to earn a degree. 

Final issue--encouraging these students to borrow $20-30k and facilitating the path to do so is downright predatory. As an advisor about 80-90% of my students could be considered a vulnerable  population. I had students with a clear intellectual disability, students who were homeless, students in crisis situations, students who are employed, retail employees who have never worked in the industry in which they're pursuing a degree. Don't worry though, they have more charts that a Middle schooler could poke holes in with regard to projected outcome and loan repayment.

review_title: Great People Make SNHU a Lovely Place to Work
pros: Everyone I have encountered at SNHU, from the hiring team to the department teams, have been exceptionally friendly and helpful. I really enjoy working for SNHU and would definitely recommend others to apply.
cons: The type of instruction I do does not have a ton of job security (it always depends on the amount of students who sign up), but I knew that when I joined. Either way, SNHU is a great place to work!

cons: Where do I start? Run far away. First of all, it has become an admissions sweatshop there where all they do is care about numbers and not the students. Management is actually incompetent and do not hold any actual degrees in  most cases. If you actually look at management linked in profile you can see that they switch from job to job before becoming employed at SNHU and got promoted due to who they know and not what they know. The management discriminates against people for many reasons but rewards employees who look the part and lack any real skill set or talent. They think that they know what they are doing but if they keep on this path they will crash and burn in collections and retention numbers. HR turns a blind eye to what is actually going on and allows the culture to be one of racism, discrimination and a hostile work environment. I couldn't wait to get out fast enough- the sad thing is that the hourly employees do care but they don't know any better to know what they are being controlled and not allowed to actually help students. There are no admissions requirements and anyone can get in so why does an interview actually exist?

review_title: Love being part of a great team!
pros: I was able to learn so many essential skills that is going to propel me into my career. Working for a forward thinking, leading the pack and innovative company is a great benefit.
cons: It is hard to think of negatives about SNHU. The benefits are fantastic and they give the tools for personal development. I guess my only complaint would be the pay. But it very similar to the Higher Education Industry.

job_title: Academic Technology Support Analyst in Manchester, NH
pros: There are many pros to working for SNHU- the pay is solid, time off is plentiful, the people are all very nice and try to create a supportive work environment and the benefits are top notch! I am so pleased to be at SNHU.
cons: It is a large organization, so patience is a virtue when completing tasks, but I have learned to like the slower pace after coming from a small business setting.

review_title: Beware.. "This may not be the place for you..."
pros:
The insurance, retirement and education benefits are awesome. They have an employees' association which bargains for the benefits, which is sort of like a quasi-union, but they don't protect people from employment abuses. The benefits are super inexpensive and the retirement fund is contributed to by the college. It is an old fashioned pension, meaning you contribute nothing! You are vested after 3 years..but it could be sooner according to hours worked. It is some secret formula they use. So try to stay until you are vested and you can walk away with a good sized rollover.  I was a salaried employee so I don't know what the deal is for hourly employees.
Another pro is that  the school's reputation is marketed in such a way that it seems fantastic. It is not what it seems, but when you tell people you work at SNHU, they gush. It looks good on your resume but It is all a giant facade.
cons:
This is just my experience, but I have heard the same from many others:

Salary is very low for experienced, but non-management level employees. 

Lack of actual managing- there are probably more supervisors, managers and directors and AVPs than I have ever seen in an organization, yet it is a disorganized chaotic mess.. which leads to...

Lack of  a clear understanding of roles, and responsibilities, "role confusion." People overstepping, working on or taking over your projects without you even knowing it for the sake of recognition. If you have a good idea, someone else will claim it is theirs. If you bring this up, you are told you are the problem.

Continually changing initiatives and direction to the point that nothing is ever getting completed. It's like going in circles with nothing ever coming to completion. Look before you leap.. they have never heard of that before. Think about consequences, the big picture. Horrible project management.  If you bring this up, you will be told you cannot deal with change.

You are often left out of meetings and communications needed to do your job. It is very much like high school with the "in" clique continuously Skyping and gossiping all day long. If you are not "in" you are at a serious disadvantage when it comes to communication.

You are not promoted on accomplishments, skill, attention to detail or loyalty.  A select group are continuously promoted to newly created bogus supervisory positions  in order to be given salary increases and leveled up, while those who do the actual work and have been dedicated employees are left in their original positions with minimal compensation increases and are often the ones who get stuck with the less than  "plum" projects. If you bring this up, you will be told you are not qualified for a promotion.

With sudden and often changes in direction, many employees' work is taken away and given to others, with no communication as to what the reason is. Sometimes there is even a duplication of efforts. The work is dwindled and dwindled away until the employee either quits, tries to find their own work, or complains. It is like being cast off of an island with no direction. When you try to find your own direction, you are told you are disruptive, inadequate, or a trouble maker and you are often put on an improvement plan. It really makes me question the efficiency of the organization. Maybe the department I was in was over staffed. The more people this happened to, the more I realized that this is a calculated way of getting employees to resign, and because they are well performing, they have no reason to fire them. They FORCE you out.

If you bring this up, you are told  "this is not the place for you...."

Putting all of this together, I should have realized that a lot of it amounted to bullying and a grievance should have been filed.  It was an experience for me, but not a growth experience. It is sad because it could have been a good position, but it did not make use of my skills. 

Make no mistake, if they don't want you there, they will force you out by withholding work, exclusion, lack of communication, and personal attacks.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Excellent University to work for and to attend. The university just recently upgraded learning management system and it is progressive.
cons: Schuedling for classes to teach needs improvement. You may go 6 months without being notified to teach unless you make a call to inquire.

pros: SNHU supports all staff incredibly well. Competitive benefits, lots of opportunities for professional development and advancement, and the atmosphere is one of creative collaboration.

They say they are "student centric, have" but their students do have critical thinking skills and try to bully adjuncts into giving better grades. It does work too; I was told to give out grades. You have no support working here, and the environment is abysmal.

review_title: Disorganized, directionless, unfocused, and unprofessional group committed to keeping bar low.
pros:
Initially appear friendly, but by day one warning signs from HR. 

Generally speaking, it  seems like if you have been there a while or hired by a friend, you can do no work and pretend like you know what what you are doing, and no one will say anything to you. That must be nice if you are one of them.

These were negatives to me, but may be attractive to someone who hired into that role. 

“Free classes” but don’t me get started
cons:
low quality of work expected, “leaders” not motivated to 
develop environment or people, oddly punitive and short sighted, lack basic skills and knowledge in field, unprofessional —people will regularly skip out on meetings without warning, surf the web, operate by exclusion, general disregard for wellbeing of employees, 

Middle to Upper level management unmotivated and not held accountable for creating and/or facilitating good working environment. They want to clock in and clock out.  Manage like they are running a Burger King.

General lack of direction and passion to achieve.

Manager very proud he did not attain his corporate goals, made clear there was no consequences for success/failure. Unable to articulate what he needed from me . 

Parking for new people will require a 20 -25 minute commute from your car to work. that is, if you are lucky enough to get one of the inconveniently scheduled busses . and then do it again on way home. they make it clear they will consider firing if they catch parking malfeasance if your not on time for work.

information management very poor. technology and software resources and access were either not available or needed to purchase myself. 

no effort from management or hr to facilitate success of new people. employee hiring  strategy seems be to resemble their admissions policy except 

Make it seem like flexible  environment but in practice seems the opposite.

A sprinkle of below the surface ethnocentrism. NH not diverse overall  and SNHU won’t be anyone’s beacon of hope

pros: Good benefit package and salary.
cons: Lack of accountability of  management to adequately address internal program issues.  Deans/directors of nursing program lack experience to lead and allow unethical student conduct to occur.

pros: Close to downtown, coaching is weekly, fair amount of tranparency from CEO, quarterly town hall meetings for updates
cons: Admission is segregated from other departments due to being chained to desk and a half hour lunch break that doesn't allow time to leave the mill. Management has a 'gotcha' mentality that has led to bad morale and shaming for underperformance or mistakes.  Although coaching is weekly it lacks employee participation with quality assurance phone reviews that are different based off of which manager they report to. Decisions are made off of favoritism and lack metrics to qualify deserving candidates, there is no solidified track to follow to be promoted other than high performance which doesnt guarantee good leadership qualities. Information leaks are rampant and people know who is liked and not liked and this fuels the rumor mill. There is little communication to counselors about the competitiveness of the field of online education and how important their role is in establishing a relationship with students to help find successful potential graduates. They are disengaged. Multiple people have left department to find better work environments and have nothing nice to say about working at SNHU which has created a bad name in New Hampshire by word of mouth. A random service employee said they heard SNHU owns you meaning no work life balance. Former employees keep in contact with current employees and most stay for the health benefits, tuition benefit, and paycheck rather than believing in the school, many complained about lack of annual increase to keep up with cost of living. Employees with bad attitudes and bad behaviors go unaddressed so the cancer and resentment spreads across the floor.

pros:
Easy work as a professor, if you want to teach students who have failed elsewhere and are not up to the task of learning in a rigorous academic a environment, then you're in for a treat at SNHU. Just copy and paste comments and you're done. SNHU doesn't care as long as you tell the students they are doing well.     

The insurance is cheap and not bad.

Lots of freedom as most full-time faculty in COCE are remote.  

Pay is not terrible and even got a bonus (small stipend).
cons:
Probably too numerous to list here in the space provided, but SNHU COCE  is all about making revenue as a result of accepting anyone with a pulse for their students.  Their entire mission is to rake in money while they provide a completely watered down curriculum.  Of course, students are praised and told how great they are doing in classes.  Students almost all get A's as the grading rubrics are skewed that way. So, in the long run, students "succeed" at SNHU by passing the 5th grade curriculum, but when they enter the workforce, they fail because they have neither the knowledge nor the skills to compete with others from competing universities.  SNHU doesn't care about this nor about their students once they graduate and are out the door.  Not their problem anymore!   They already have their money and can fund their TV commercials and ridiculously overpaid administrators who do nothing but sit back and give orders to their "underlings". Many are former Western Governors University employees who left there (or were fired) and found a home at COCE.

The full-time faculty are mandated by the administration who control everything.  Full-time faculty in COCE don't even have an opportunity to change the online BlackBoard sites to add their own content.  Even the syllabus is off limits to all faculty. They can't select textbooks for courses and can't add in lectures to the online courses. The administration hires "subject matter experts"  (and I use that term very loosely since they also hire anyone with a pulse to fill these positions) who work for cheap stipends and SNHU gets what they pay for.  Faculty are treated like "pawns" and are kept out of all important discussions and decisions, which are made exclusively by administrators who think only of making money. If you want to be treated poorly and not respected for being a scholar, then SNHU COCE is for you.

If you think SNHU is different and is a success where other online institutions fail, forget it.  They only portray that their students succeed where other institutions have failed them.  That part IS true. Their students failed at other universities because they SHOULD have failed.  Students are incredibly low quality at SNHU COCE and really shouldn't be in an institution of higher learning. The world needs people with trade skills and there are those that should not have college degrees.  SNHU has found a way to capitalize on these folks, take their hard earned money, tell them they are doing great and then send them into the world with a subpar education.  SNHU COCE teaches students very little and sets them up for future workforce failure. It is essentially "academic fraud". 

I was lied to in my interview and told that there were opportunities to advance my career.  Hah!  I was later told that things change and we are "now going in a different direction".  I would say that is true: SNHU is going downward into a spiral!

By the way, this is more than just "sour grapes".  There are a number of FTF who will be leaving as soon as they land another position.  SNHU is in for a big fall!  Good luck on your future accreditation!

pros: Amazing benefits, above average industry pay and good people.  I've been with SNHU for just over 3 years and it's been an amazing place to grow professionally.  Opportunities abound for the willing!  Have an idea?  Make a suggestion and they will listen.  Truly a great place to work!
cons: None, we have good people here and good things will continue to happen!
